urn:contentItem:5WS0-HY31-JC0X-H488-00000-00Monzo PIN breach a GDPR fine in the making?2019-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY & TELECOMMUNICATIONSMonzo PIN breach a GDPR fine in the making?

Monzo has told some 500,000 of its customers to change their personal identification number (PIN) after the challenger bank incorrectly stored them in its own internal systems.

The digital bank said that it had inadvertently copied around a fifth of UK customers' PINs to encrypted log files. These log files could only be accessed by Monzo engineers and were stored for up to six months in this location. Monzo became aware of the PIN breach on Friday and rolled out an update to the app the following day. By Monday it had deleted the incorrectly stored data and sent an email to those affected asking them to change their PIN.

Monzo also recommends that customers update to the latest version of the app. Monzo said that nobody outside of the bank had access to the PINs and that there is no evidence that the information has been used to commit fraud. "We've checked all the accounts that have been affected by this bug thoroughly, and confirmed the information hasn't been used to commit fraud," Monzo said in a blog post. "Just in case, we've messaged everyone that's been affected to let them know they should change their PIN by going to a cash machine." Jake Moore, cybersecurity specialist at ESET, said: "If a bank tells you to change your PIN then things are not going very well. In an ideal world, not even the engineers should have had access to the codes, which would have mitigated this problem. "But then again, like any breach, most never think it will ever happen. Obviously, changing your PIN number is advised, but if all of your cards use the same PIN, it would be best practice to change them too - just like in a password breach." Did the Monzo PIN error breach GDPR?Monzo appears to have reported the breach to the Information Commissioner's Office, the UK's data regulator, within the 72 hour period stipulated under the General Data Protection Regulation. The ICO told the Financial Times: "We are aware of an incident involving Monzo and we will be assessing the matter." Robert Wassall, director of legal services for cybersecurity firm ThinkMarble, told Verdict that the Monzo PIN breach is something the ICO would "likely be very concerned about" because it involves a financial institution. Wassall pointed out that 500,000 customers is a similar number of people compromised in the British Airways breach, for which the ICO recently levied a record £183m GDPR fine. BA fell victim to a cyberattack in which hackers stole payment details from the company's website. The airline fell afoul of the 'Breach of Principle of Integrity and confidentiality', a key GDPR principle that requires organisations to uphold appropriate technical and organisational measures to process personal data securely. Wassall said that the Monzo PIN breach would likely fall under the same principle. In a May blog post, information commissioner Elizabeth Denham said the ICO would be focusing on this principle for the second half of 2019: "Organisations need to shift their focus to accountability with a real evidenced understanding of the risks to individuals in the way they process data and how those risks should be mitigated," she wrote. Jasmit Sagoo, senior director, head of technology UK & Ireland at Veritas, an enterprise data protection firm, said: "Poor data hygiene is bad for business, threatening the foundation of the customer relationship and the organisation itself. "Leaving data disorganised also makes it vulnerable, opening it up to potential bad actors and exponentially increasing the chances of a highly damaging data breach. Sensitive customer information -bank details or home addresses - is then ripe for the taking if poorly protected. "Good data hygiene is not easy to achieve, but it's increasingly necessary. To compete in a marketplace where trust is a valued commodity, businesses must prove they are responsible with customer data and meet their data requirements." The Monzo PIN breach comes at a time when the bank is looking to expand into the US. The bank, which has no physical branches, is currently valued at £2bn. Read more: The Bank of Amazon: How big tech is disrupting banking

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5JS4-SJY1-DYT4-K018-00000-00Moody Mr Market2016-05-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisOPINION & EDITORIALMoody Mr MarketToby Shapshak

Moody Mr Market

Unrealistic expectations by Wall Street of what the technology giants' growth should be are affecting the firms' performance

Pattern Recognition

Imagine you're the biggest search engine in the world, and in the midst of a major transition from high-cost desktop advertising to lower-margin mobile ads - yet you still manage to bring in US$20.26bn. You also add $10bn to your cash stockpile, taking it to $75bn. But you missed Wall Street's revenue estimates by $120m. Yes, just $120m on revenue of $20bn.

Last month the markets hammered Google's new holding company, Alphabet, shaving 6% off its market share in after-hours trading on one day.

As The New York Times said: & European regulators brought the hammer down on Google this week, and investors barely blinked. But when the company's first-quarter numbers came in a little light on Thursday afternoon, its stock immediately plummeted.& Colin Gillis of BGC Partners told the paper: & There's nothing wrong with this company. They spent a bit more and took in a bit less than we thought, so Mr Market is having a mood swing. But it was a fine quarter.& Something similar happened over at Microsoft, which also announced its results last month. In a harsh environment Microsoft had pretty solid earnings, despite the PC market - where Microsoft has traditionally made all its money - declining by 9%, which dragged chipmaker Intel's market cap down. Its revenue fell to $20.53bn from $21.73bn the year before, which, granted, doesn't look good.

But considering that the largest maker of software has managed to reinvent itself as a cloud-service provider, second only to Amazon, you'd expect a little goodwill from Wall Street.

Twitter is in the same boat. The results it announced last month were up 36% year on year to $595m, but missed the Wall Street average expectation of $607.8m. That's a $12.8m difference. The number of its users, which dropped 2m in the previous quarter to 305m, bounced up to 310m. Still, it lost 14% in after-hours trading.

& Here's a company that makes $500m a quarter on 140-character messages, and it's considered an abject failure by Wall Street,& author Douglas Rushkoff told me at the South by Southwest conference in Austin, Texas, in March.

This was based on Twitter's revenue of $710m in the last quarter of 2015, which, by the way, was an increase of 90% over the previous year's quarter.

& Twitter's mistake was selling itself to venture capital and then selling itself to Wall Street in an IPO. That's because those investors want to make a hundred times, a thousand times, on their investment,& he said.

And it will get worse, he added.

& The problem is that Twitter will now have to sacrifice the quality of what it's doing, that Twitter is going to have to destroy itself on some level to try to extract more value from its marketplace.

& The tragedy is that a $500m-a-quarter business is a failure; that it can't stay on.& Wall Street is a cruel beast and its obsession with quarterly growth is killing the companies listed on it.

It is also in danger of killing the innovation these companies have become recognised for.

In the past, only Apple CEO Steve Jobs and Amazon chief Jeff Bezos were able to thumb their nose at these unrealistic growth expectations. But now even Apple's share price has fallen to earth, as its unprecedented 13-year run of quarter growth has come to an end.

Amazon, which generally tends to plough its profits back into growing its various businesses, unusually declared a profit, raking in $29.13bn revenue compared with $22.72bn the previous year.

A not insignificant portion of that comes from its cloud-computing business - a chunk of which was developed in Cape Town, in case you don't know - and not the lean margins of the e-commerce online store that it is mostly known for.

The problem isn't the performance of these big tech firms but Wall Street's unrealistic expectations of what their growth should be.

Simply put, Wall Street is the problem.

Shapshak is editor-in-chief and publisher of Stuff magazine (stuff.co.za).Follow him on Twitter: @shapshak

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TCP-0R81-JD2S-24D3-00000-00Moody’s: asset managers beware the Apple and Facebook fund2018-09-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisMoody’s: asset managers beware the Apple and Facebook fundYoosof Farah

Big tech firms will take a slice of financial services in future, launching their own index funds and robo-advisors according to Moody's.

Big tech firms like Apple, Facebook and Google owner Alphabet will wrestle a slice of retail financial services away from asset managers and other finance firms, launching their own index funds and robo-advisors.

That’s according to a report by Moody’s, which warns that technology firms will offer a better value proposition to consumers with better user experience, lower costs and more innovative features.

In a central scenario forecasted by the ratings agency, finance firms will cede a portion of control over financial services to the big tech firms, with many finance companies developing digital platforms or niche services as a result.

According to the report, tech companies are most likely to enter finance through ‘simple products that are most core to their businesses’ like payments, creating transaction accounts through money market funds or partnerships with banks.

Once created and with financial value stored there, they become the gateway for converting client funds into longer term financial products, Moody’s said.

In launching new financial products, the ratings agency believes technology firms will likely focus on the front end of the value chain touching the client, and as value grows within a platform, ‘other products will be developed whose primary purpose is to grow value, such as low-cost index funds.’

It added that financial advice would follow with offerings such as investment and savings advice, and solutions like, robo-advice and financial planning.

The report continued: ‘As this range of product offerings grows and meets more financial needs, client engagement will increase and consumers will have greater incentives to stay with a given tech brand.

‘Tech companies, meanwhile, will be able to capture new types of consumer financial data. Against a backdrop of heightened public concerns over data privacy and potentially increased regulatory scrutiny, we anticipate that such data will remain immensely valuable: in addition to payment and purchase data, financial data also provides insight into a consumer’s economic profile and needs.’

It highlighted Alipay and WeChat Pay, part of Alibaba and Tencent respectively, in China as examples of tech firms moving into financial services, with both offering mobile payments, money market funds and insurance policies, with wealth management products available via third parties.

Moody’s said the biggest threat to asset managers in particular is ceding control of customer relationships to tech companies.

It highlighted mutual funds in particular as a risk, with the growth of the fund management industry increasing the ‘homogeneity’ of product performance, making distribution an ‘increasingly important’ means for asset managers to gain a competitive edge.

Moody’s said the biggest threat to asset managers in particular is ceding control of customer relationships to tech companies.

It highlighted mutual funds in particular as a risk, with the growth of the fund management industry increasing the ‘homogeneity’ of product performance, making distribution an ‘increasingly important’ means for asset managers to gain a competitive edge.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60H6-2991-JBN8-N21R-00000-00Moody's Assigns Aa2 Rating To Alphabet's Senior Debt Offering2020-08-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisCompany SignificantMoody's Assigns Aa2 Rating To Alphabet's Senior Debt Offering

(Alliance News) - Moody's Investors Service on Monday assigned an Aa2 rating to Google parent Alphabet Inc's proposed multiple tranche senior unsecured debt offering.

Three of the tranches of these bonds are expected to be sustainability bonds. Proceeds from the offering will go towards general corporate purposes, including the possible repayment of outstanding debt and eligible green and social projects.

Moody's said the rating reflect's Alphabet's "position as the world's leading Internet search engine and digital advertising facilitator through its varied Google and other properties, and its significant and growing positions in Cloud services, mobile operating systems, online video, consumer hardware and autonomous driving technology, among others."

The credit ratings agency said Alphabet has "extremely strong cash flow capability and credit measures" that are consistent with and possibly exceed its Aa2 debt ratings.

In financial 2019, Alphabet had free cash flow generation of around USD31 billion, and about USD121 billion of cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities compared to reported debt of USD4.0 billion.

"While Alphabet currently has very modest leverage (0.5 times adjusted debt to [earnings before, interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisaton]), the Aa2 rating factors in the possibility that, over time, debt could rise producing debt to EBITDA of up to about 1.0 times (using Moody's standard adjustments)," said Moody's.

The ratings agency highlighted Alphabet's most significant social risks as stemming from "regulatory challenges" to its strong market position and business practises and said that this "has long been the primary concern and risk for Alphabet's credit standing."

"These challenges could impede Alphabet's core segment expansion. The company has accrued over USD9 billion in fines by the European Commission related to various decisions finding that Google infringed European competition law. The company has appealed the fines," Moody's said.

Moody's pointed to the "broad and bipartisan shift in tone from US regulators, lawmakers and presidential candidates" when it comes to "Big Tech" companies like Amazon Inc, Apple Inc, and Alphabet. This has resulted in "a broad bipartisan investigation into potential antitrust law violations by Google".

Alphabet's stable outlook, Moody's said, reflects an expectation that the company will maintain its market position within desktop and mobile search and display advertising and includes the expectation for its "very liquid and mildly levered balance sheet" to be maintained.

The rating might be upgraded if "management commits to maintaining financial policies that are consistent with a higher credit rating" while a downgrade could occur if "there is deterioration or regulatory interference in the company's core business model" resulting in erosion of profitability, cash flow generation, and market positions.

Class 'A' Alphabet shares were down 0.5% at USD1,481.00 on Monday in New York, while its 'C' class shares were down 0.7% at USD1,473.38.

By Anna Farley; annafarley@alliancenews.com

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TBT-7DD1-DXCW-D044-00000-00Moody's: Big tech a real threat to financial firms in retail services2018-09-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisMoody's: Big tech a real threat to financial firms in retail services

New York City: Moody's Investors Service has issued the following news release: Global technology firms' innovations and expansion into retail financial services will slice a portion of financial firms' control of their user base, Moody's Investors Service says in a new report. In response, financial firms will accelerate digitalization efforts as online ecosystems already controlled by large global technology businesses grow further. Moody's examines how this growth will affect incumbent financial firms, including banks, insurers, asset managers and brokers.

In a central scenario, these firms will cede a portion of their control over the distribution of retail financial services despite efforts to increase their presence on digital platforms. In an alternate scenario, big tech firms would control a larger share of distribution and manufacturing, eventually leading to the displacement of a number of financial incumbents, particularly those that fail to execute timely and comprehensive digital strategies. User experience has become the primary factor in retaining and acquiring new customers, and will play a key role in determining where and how consumers will access their financial needs. Losing control over a portion of customer relationships, which is credit negative to financial firms, stems from big tech companies expanding distribution and inclusion of retail financial services within their ecosystems. Initially, the provision of these services will likely be done in partnerships with financial incumbents. "Big tech companies have an advantage over financial firms since they have significant experience in optimizing customers' user experience and have been able to grow their market share in part because consumers find their products add value, are easy and convenient to use, and have increasingly compelling digital ecosystems." according to Moody's Vice President Stephen Tu, one of the authors of the report "Through innovation, tech companies can provide value in financial services in entirely new ways," says Warren Kornfeld, a Moody's senior vice president and co-author of the report. "This is accomplished by offering fresh capabilities through aggregation and customization of products, services and offerings, and through large-scale networks or digital communities." However, while well-known big tech firms are potential sources of competition in retail financial services, they are likely to avoid manufacturing financial products due to regulatory burdens. Though steering clear of directly manufacturing financial products such as deposits and lending, big tech will continue to expand in the distribution and inclusion of financial services in their ecosystems, which could lead to big tech controlling a large portion of the consumer relationship. Thus, turning a portion of financial firms primarily into manufacturers. The report "Financial Institutions -- Global: Threat of big tech disruption is real," is available to Moody's subscribers at https://www.moodys.com /researchdocumentcontentpage.aspx?docid=PBC_1120094. To listen to our podcast with the key takeaways from this report please visit   www.moodys.com /bigtechpodcast

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5DM8-KDT1-DXH2-62NX-00000-00Moody's Corp at Wells Fargo Technology, Media & Telecom Conference - Final2014-11-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexis111314a5528719.719Moody's Corpat Wells Fargo Technology, Media & Telecom Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Ray McDaniel

Moody's Corporation- President & CEO

Conference Call Participants

* Bill Warmington

Wells Fargo Securities - Analyst

Presentation

BILL WARMINGTON, ANALYST, WELLS FARGO SECURITIES: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the Moody's Corporationpresentation here at the Wells Fargo conference. With us today we are honored to have Ray McDaniel, the CEO of Moody's Corporation. Ray started at Moody's back in 1987 as a credit analyst and has been the CEO of the Company since 2005. And I was looking it up -- when you became CEO back in April 2005 the stock was at about $40 and as of yesterday the close was above $100, an all-time high. So congratulations on that.

RAY MCDANIEL, PRESIDENT & CEO, MOODY'S CORPORATION: It hasn't been a completely straight line.

BILL WARMINGTON: Fair point, fair point. Now, Ray, even though I think everybody in this room is familiar with -- from Moody's from a rating agencies standpoint, I think it might be helpful just to spend a couple of minutes to talk about all of Moody's product lines. So think of a quick overview to level set.

RAY MCDANIEL: Sure. And you are right, most people, when I mention Moody's, they think of rating agency. And the rating agency does comprise about two-thirds of our total business, total revenue and a more significant component of our operating income.

But the other third of the business is in its own right a -- about a $1 billion business and that is Moody's Analytics, which is comprised of three reporting units, one called research, data and analytics; the other is enterprise risk solutions; and then we have a professional service business, provides training, credit-rating services, certification, things of that sort.

The enterprise risk solutions business is a business which develops risk management and risk measurement models for financial institutions around the world. That business has been growing very nicely. And it is really meeting a number of demands, many of them coming from regulators looking at the adequacy of bank capital, stress testing solutions, processes around stress testing reporting, things of that sort.

And then as a -- working back up the ladder to the research data and analytics unit, we publish a vast amount of commentary, credit and economic commentary, as well as data sources, a lot of proprietary data that we make available to the markets in that unit.

So that is a quick overview of the Moody's Analytics business and, as compared to the rating agency, which has our four reporting units that I think people are generally familiar with: corporate finance rating; structured finance; public project and infrastructure finance; and financial institutions.

Questions and Answers

BILL WARMINGTON: Perfect, thank you. Now let's talk about China for a moment. On Monday you were in China, you were giving a speech at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation CEO Summit -- make sure I read that correctly. And I wanted to ask what kind of an opportunity China presents for Moody's?

RAY MCDANIEL: It presents I will call it an interesting opportunity and hopefully a significant opportunity. China's domestic bond markets are developing. They've been expanding that market in a reasonably significant way over the last decade or so. But it is still a market which is very heavily bank financed.

And so the process that we have talked about, you and I have talked about in other forums, of disintermediation is in its early stages in China. So that domestic market opportunity we think could be very significant over time.

The reason I say the Chinese opportunity is interesting is right now that market is not open to Moody's to operate as a domestic rating agency, so we operate in a joint venture, we watch that market and talk with policymakers about the likely timing and extent of a market opening and access to the country.

It is part -- as most of you will already well know, it is part of a much broader dialogue going on on both a bilateral basis and a multilateral basis in terms of the access to the country, access to markets in the country by a variety of industries, including the financial services industry, but really many industries.

And then in addition to that we have a good cross-border business where we provide credit ratings for the largest Chinese entities that are accessing the debt markets in the United States, the Euro market. And we have about 160 rated companies and state owned enterprises that have already established rating relationships with Moody's as part of that cross-border exercise.

And then the last component is we do provide professional services and risk management software through our Moody's Analytics business to some of the largest Chinese financial institutions.

BILL WARMINGTON: Got you. So how does that market evolve then? When does it evolve to a point where it can support actionable third-party ratings? I mean I have heard you talk in the past you will draw a parallel with the Japanese market.

RAY MCDANIEL: Yes. And this is one of several very critical questions in trying to judge the market opportunity in China, because to date there have been very few bonds that have been permitted to default. The model has been that there has been support either from municipalities or banks, but there has been institutional support for companies that have distress in the bond market.

So whether or not as part of the opening of the market and the state council's intention to allow market sources to play a more decisive role, whether that translates into permitting companies that run into credit problems to default on their bonds is a very important question if you are providing bond ratings. If nothing is ever permitted to default the product we have to offer is arguably not very useful.

And that is where I draw the analogy to Japan, which has experienced almost no bond defaults over the last several decades despite very obvious distress for a large number of companies in that market. But as a matter of managing the market and policy, those distressed credit situations have been absorbed by the banking system and ultimately the tax payers. So we have to see which way the Chinese market develops.

BILL WARMINGTON: Well, I'm going to go backward in your travels then to last week when you were in London and ask your thoughts on the state of the European financial markets.

RAY MCDANIEL: Well, I happened to be there at the same time that the European Commission revised -- released some of the revised outlook numbers for the European Union in terms of 2015 outlook, GDP outlook. And there were downward revisions.

And so the outlook for Europe next year is not one where we would be anticipating a lot of growth. Modest growth is included in the forecast and obviously varies from country to country. The UK is expected to have pretty good growth, certainly on a relative basis, as is Ireland. But some of the big economies, including Germany and France, are expected to be in the very low single-digits, around 1%.

So it looks as though we are going to be at this point continuing in a very low interest rate environment. The European Central Bank has already taken certain steps, announced certain steps for easing quantitative easing. And that's certainly I think an appropriate position for them to be taking given the expectations.

But I think it is going to be some time before we see more substantial growth coming out of Europe. I hope it is sooner rather than later. That is obviously good for the global economy if it does happen, but right now the outlook and forecasts are pretty modest.

BILL WARMINGTON: Well, now, it seems like there is a big opportunity for Moody's in Europe with disintermediation being more of a bank loan market than a bond market. Now is there some potential that that transition is able to accelerate and offset some of that softness?

RAY MCDANIEL: I don't think -- I would not expect it to accelerate from where it is now. But it has already stepped up over the last few years, really since 2010. And so, the disintermediation has increased in Europe and I would expect it to continue. I don't expect that to fall off. And that is really from a -- from Moody's standpoint that is beneficial in a couple of ways.

Certainly to the extent that assets are moving from the banking system into the bond market that creates more bonds for us to rate at MIS. And it establishes -- as importantly, it establishes new rating relationships which tend to continue over time.

Once a relationship is established, once a company is in the bond market, has its name known in the bond market it is often reluctant to lose that additional access to capital and liquidity that the bond market provides.

In addition, it develops ongoing monitoring fees for us as each year we follow a larger and larger number of companies. So to the extent that a Company asks for a rating and then we establish a monitoring relationship, the recurring revenue base for Moody's will increase accordingly.

BILL WARMINGTON: Got you. I wanted to get your thoughts on Mario Draghi's stimulus for structured finance and what implications that potentially has for the issuance market.

RAY MCDANIEL: I'm sorry, for the --?

BILL WARMINGTON: For structured finance, his plans for that market.

RAY MCDANIEL: Oh, yeah. And as you are aware, we had a strong third-quarter in US structured finance.

BILL WARMINGTON: Yes.

RAY MCDANIEL: And that was really driven by very high activity in the collateralized loan obligation, CLO market. Now, the recovery in structured finance has not been as broad-based as would be ideal, the mortgage-backed securities market is still relatively dormant. And we've seen activity in other areas of asset-backed securities, commercial mortgage-backed securities. But not back to pre-crisis levels by any means.

And then some parts of the market are being affected by regulation. Certainly the role that Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac are playing in the mortgage market and what that -- the implications for the private label mortgage-backed securities, as well as some additional rules that are coming for CLOs in the next couple of years, you see regulation around that. I'm happy to talk about that.

But I should shift over and also say that the European securitization market remains very soft. And so, the growth that we've seen and recovery that we've seen in the US has not been replicated in Europe. And it has gotten to the point where I think European policymakers would like to see additional securitization as part of one of a number of things that they think may help restart and generate some economic momentum across the continent broadly.

BILL WARMINGTON: Got it. Well, we've touched on Asia, we've touched on Europe. I wanted to ask if maybe you could comment on the opportunities for Moody's in emerging markets more broadly -- other than we have touched on Asia and China, but --.

RAY MCDANIEL: Yes, the individual emerging markets remain a small part of our business. But when we look at the emerging markets as a collective, yes, it is becoming certainly more important. Business is expanding, not only in Latin America where you would expect it, but we are seeing growth in Middle East, for example, project and infrastructure financing. In Eastern Europe, South and Southeast Asia -- we are really seeing growth in all of these markets. And I would include now Africa and that.

It is not something I would've mentioned in prior years, but we are starting to see ratings and rating requests coming from sovereigns and financial institutions in Africa. And that is where we would expect it to begin before it moves more broadly out in the corporate sector.

So I think that is not going to be a significant story for a few years. But it is actually nice to be able to talk about it for the first time and give it a mention. Cyclically I think it is interesting to look at the emerging markets in the context of the potential for -- well, what we've seen and the potential further for the strengthening dollar. And the movement of capital potentially from emerging market opportunities to the dollar.

We saw that a little over a year ago when the first talk about the taper began and there was a bit of a flight of capital to the dollar. I would expect we would see some of that again if we start to see interest rates increase and as the dollar strengthens. But I don't think that the central scenario is for any kind of panicked flight out of the emerging markets. I think it would be much more moderate at this point.

I think the markets have adjusted themselves to the expectation that we would have a stronger dollar given that we are ready to embark on some monetary tightening in the United States. But we've got monetary easing going on elsewhere around the world and how that changes the relative attractiveness of currencies.

BILL WARMINGTON: I wanted to also ask about the US market, since we have touched around everything else but that, and get your thoughts on the -- three weeks ago it sounded like the pipelines were looking pretty good for much of the US market. I just wanted to see if you had any updated thoughts as we head into the end of the year and into 2015, how you are feeling about issuance levels and the health of the overall market?

RAY MCDANIEL: Yes. I mean as we described a few weeks ago, I think we would characterize in the US market the bank loan and spec grade bond pipelines as being average with the investment grade pipeline being good. And interest rates certainly have remained low, no surprises there.

And I think as we have seen really throughout the last couple of years, almost week to week we have periods of strong activity and then the market goes soft and then strong activity again. And that has continued. So I think the first couple of weeks in October were pretty soft and then it picked up a little as companies moved out of blackout periods and there was a little more stability and perceived stability in the market.

BILL WARMINGTON: Now the M&A pipeline sounded like it was particularly strong and that there was a lot of activity in that market. And that there was potentially a lot of financing in the wings, if you will, looking to come out.

RAY MCDANIEL: And this is one of the areas we would look not only for the fourth quarter but looking out into 2015. If we assume that we are going to have higher rates in 2015, higher official rates, and looking at what that does to refinancing. Well, a lot of refinancing, especially investment grade refinancing, happens on a pretty regular basis as bonds mature. But opportunistic refinancing may hit a soft patch with an increasing rate environment.

And so, we would look for mergers and acquisition activity, capital expenditure, borrowing for share repurchase, etc., to pick up any slack that we might see in the spec grade opportunistic refi market. That being said, I think that inflation expectations are still relatively modest, that would indicate that even if there is an increasing rate environment it may not be dramatic.

And the fact that not all economies around the world are moving in the same direction I think is also going to act as a governor on inflation and perhaps give the Fed a little more flexibility in its monetary policy.

BILL WARMINGTON: So I wanted to shift and ask some questions on Moody's Analytics. The enterprise risk solutions especially. It just seems like there is a big opportunity there in terms of stress tests. If you go back to 2009 there were what, 19 banks that -- in the US that underwent stress tests.

RAY MCDANIEL: Yes.

BILL WARMINGTON: Now it seems like it's not only gotten big in the US, it has now spread to Europe. And maybe you could talk a little bit about the opportunity that that presents for you guys.

RAY MCDANIEL: Sure. Well as you know, Europe just completed its stress test --.

BILL WARMINGTON: It didn't look good, either.

RAY MCDANIEL: It was -- I think it was about as expected, at least about as we expected. But you are right, this does present a very attractive opportunity we think.

Because regulators, if they are going to permit institutions to pay dividends, to engage in share repurchase, increase dividends or engage in share repurchase, etc., they really want to make sure that at this point they have gotten comfortable with capital adequacy, they have gotten comfortable with risk management practices, that the banks have performed well through the stress testing process.

And so, this really provides we think a significant demand for something that we believe we are uniquely well-positioned to provide.

The other thing I would just add to this is it is really initially a lot of the bank customers that we were talking to you were looking for an answer to satisfy a question that was being asked of them. And we expect that as we look forward it is really going to become much more about a process than an answer.

And this is where having an installed platform that can produce replicable results that are comparative period on period and are understood and accepted by oversight authorities really becomes a very important part of this opportunity.

We think that we have got a very good product for satisfying all of those demands. And so, that is why we feel so good about this opportunity. And why, as you well know, we have really been pushing the top line, the sales and not trying to stress the near-term profitability of that business.

Because we think that we are in a period of time where acquiring the sales and making the installations is really the best way for long-term success in this area because it is going to be a very sticky product once it is installed.

This is something that is installed throughout a financial institution and is meeting its regulatory obligations. So -- we are -- I described it before as being a bit in a land grab phase of this market opportunity.

BILL WARMINGTON: Do you have any competition there?

RAY MCDANIEL: Yes, most of our competition is interestingly not the usual suspects you would see on the ratings side, it is more the big tech firms. And they obviously are well schooled in technology development and design. But so are we in this area.

We made the acquisition of KMV back in 2002, of Fermat in 2008, Barrie & Hibbert shortly after that. So a group of software development and risk modeling, risk analytics firms that we've been able to integrate and create this more complete platform for risk management, risk measurement.

And we also have relationships at financial institutions with the risk officers and the risk departments. And we think that that is the more important place for us to -- for anyone to be explaining their product and service in this area as opposed to the technology side of a financial institution.

BILL WARMINGTON: Agreed, agreed. So let's talk about margins. And you have a high-class problem, you are at close to 43% on the operating margin side, close to 46% on the EBITDA margin side. You are at the high end of the information services peer group, which is already a fairly high margin group compared to the overall market.

And so my question is, have you started to reach the point at which -- of diminishing returns for margin expansion where it makes sense to start to reinvest some of that incremental profit back into the business? And if so where do you invest?

RAY MCDANIEL: We -- in terms of our priorities, reinvesting back into the business is the first priority. So we are not foregoing opportunities in order to achieve margin expansion. Now, if we don't see opportunities we are not going to just push money back into the business for no reason and that would potentially create some margin expansion. And I do believe we still have some margin expansion opportunities over time.

It is going to be dependent on the mix of our businesses and where we see the investment opportunities. And very specifically, if we are able to grow our Moody's Analytics business at a faster rate than the rating agency business, that is a lower margin business.

We think it is an attractive business, we think there are margin expansion opportunities in that business specifically. But it is a business that is unlikely to run at the kind of margin that the rating agency runs at. So again, if the growth is faster there that will act as a drag on margin expansion.

Where do we see the reinvestment of business? Well, recently we haven't made some acquisitions, several of them have been on the Moody's Analytics side, but we also were able to invest in a rating agency in India called ICRA.

So it is not exclusively Moody's Analytics opportunities, although it has been more weighted on that side historically and, frankly, I would expect it to be more weighted on that side going forward. There just aren't that many rating agencies that are doing something that we aren't already doing (multiple speakers) around the world.

And so, we -- it means that at the rating agency continuing to enhance the predictive content of our ratings, the quality of our research, the insight that goes into that research, how timely it is -- all of those are important investments to make to protect and grow this very good business that we have.

On the Moody's Analytics side of the business we have similar opportunities to continue to build out our enterprise risk solutions business and our professional services business. We also look for high-quality content or -- and/or proprietary data that might be suitable for addition to our research data and analytics business.

So really all three reporting units in the Moody's Analytics business we think present investment opportunities, whether it is organic investment or through acquisition activity.

The last piece of this I would say is we also have to make sure that we are investing geographically at a pace that makes sense for the markets where we want to operate. There is no point in hiring 100 analysts for a bond market that doesn't exist.

But we certainly want to be in a position where we are not lagging a market at all and ideally leading it by a bit to help that market develop in a healthy way. And so, I think everyone should anticipate that we will continue to expand our international business and in particular in the emerging markets.

BILL WARMINGTON: Now on the M&A side, any product or geographic holes that you have that you are thinking you would like to fill at some point?

RAY MCDANIEL: I think we have gotten to the point with Moody's Analytics that there are some nice to haves, but we moved past the need to have stage. And we did have some things that we needed to acquire over the last few years, or build, in order to feel that we had a sufficiently complete offering to have an attractive competitive product.

We have gotten there, we feel good about that. It doesn't mean there aren't some things we've got our eyes on, I won't mention those by name. But we do -- we are always looking and we try to be disciplined about what we are looking at. But I would hope that there is going to be some things we can do over the next year or two.

BILL WARMINGTON: Okay. That is probably a good lead into a question on professional solutions. We haven't really touched on that much. But Copal and Amba, and maybe you can talk about how those business -- just quickly talk about what they do, but also how they fit into your overall strategy?

RAY MCDANIEL: Sure. Copal Amba are two businesses which we have acquired and combined over the last couple of years, Copal in 2011 and Amba in 2013. And we've also announced our plans to acquire the last one-third stake in Copal that we did not already own and we expect to complete that in December. So we will have 100% ownership of the combined entities Copal Amba next month, we believe.

Combined they provide research services and related professional services for mostly financial institutions around the world. So they are based in India, but their customer base is really global and has some of the largest financial institutions in the world.

And it is interesting because at first blush you might say, well, okay, that might be a nice business, and it is, it has been growing well for us, it is got good margins, we like that business quite a bit. But exactly how is the fit with the rest of Moody's?

And I would step back and say again we have to look at what is happening with financial institutions globally and with financial institution regulation. Just as pressure on financial institutions is encouraging disintermediation on the rating side of the business and is encouraging demand for risk management products in the ERS business, it's also been putting pressure on bank profitability.

And so, banks are looking to have a high quality research product and service that they continue to make available to their customers at the same time they are trying to manage a cost base. And so, as they work to square that circle the service that Copal Amba provides is a very high quality but lower-cost service for the research side of these institutions businesses.

So again, it is -- really all parts of our business and in some way are being pushed by what is happening in financial services, financial institutions regulation.

BILL WARMINGTON: Okay. So I think I probably have time to sneak one last question in.

RAY MCDANIEL: Okay.

BILL WARMINGTON: So I wanted to ask about visibility in the business. Basically if you look at transaction versus recurring revenue for you, it works out to be about half and half at this point.

RAY MCDANIEL: Yes.

BILL WARMINGTON: And, but if you look at the percentage that is coming from the MIS business it tends to be more heavily weighted, roughly about two-thirds of that business being transaction-based. So how do you think about -- you're going to be giving guidance for 2005 in a couple of months. As you look out how do you then think about the visibility that you have on the business to give you the comfort on projections?

RAY MCDANIEL: Well, the recurring revenue base has been growing, it will continue to do so. Not only, and again, it is not only the recurring revenues that come out of the subscription business and our research data sales over on the Moody's Analytics side, although that is a large part of it.

But also the monitoring fees, the annual fees that we get on the rating agency side of the business as the stock of rated names grows, that creates an embedded recurring revenue base. So the larger that group of rated names becomes the more ballast we are going to have from a recurring revenue standpoint.

Now that being said, I still like transaction revenue associated with bond issuance. And I wouldn't look to fundamentally alter how we approach transaction versus recurring revenue for issuance purposes, because I believe that over time we are going to continue to see issuance volumes grow at a minimum in line with GDP.

I would say take out leveraging and deleveraging cycles you would have growth in line with GDP plus growth that comes from disintermediation on top of that. So the transaction pricing that we can get, as long as we believe that the volumes will be there, is an attractive source of revenue. There is no -- it is not discounted for a frequent issuer pricing program or something of that.

So I do like that component and I like maintaining that component even as we grow the recurring revenue base alongside of it.

BILL WARMINGTON: Okay. Ray, (multiple speakers).

RAY MCDANIEL: Thank you very much.

BILL WARMINGTON: Thank you very much for coming, enjoyed it.

RAY MCDANIEL: Thank you.

urn:contentItem:5S6B-CPJ1-DXCW-D38K-00000-00Moody's: Innovative and agile leaders will harness technology to shape the bank of the future2018-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisMoody's: Innovative and agile leaders will harness technology to shape the bank of the future


New York City: Moody's Investors Service has issued the following news release:
Digital innovation in financial services is placing a premium on efficiency and opening up competition that will continue to drive disruption across banking business segments, including payments, lending, capital markets and wealth management, Moody's Investors Service says in a new report.


Agile incumbent banks, that consistently assert digital leadership, will thrive and prosper, while laggard banks that lack the vision or resources to develop competitive digital strategies will be disrupted. Aging legacy financial platforms have created opportunities for new nimble entrants to capture a portion of banks' profits by offering more customer-focused, responsive and efficient channels.
Moody's says the bank of the future will cater to high and rapidly evolving customer expectations by harnessing key enabling technologies, leveraging increasingly mature and dependable digital distribution channels, and applying these tools across multiple businesses and product segments. Customers will gravitate to providers that best meet their demands for convenience, personalization and affordability, with privacy and data security a growing competitive differentiator. Amid the shifts in technology and consumer demand, competition will stiffen among banks, big technology companies and small fintechs.
"In the face of these threats, successful incumbent banks will be those that, either on their own or in collaboration with others, pursue aggressive digital transformation to become more efficient and responsive to evolving customer demands," Fadi Abdel Massih, a Moody's analyst and co-author of the report says. "Disintermediation of the customer relationship would be a threat to this business model if it ends up reducing banks' pricing power by transforming them into providers of a 'back-office' balance sheet for customer-facing apps/businesses."
Digitization will offer efficiency enhancement opportunities for incumbent banks through the optimization of branch networks, data collection, analysis and reporting process but not without high initial investment.
To date, regulatory requirements have been a moat protecting incumbents. The traditional, more regulated banking model -- reliant on cheap, sticky deposits -- retains a significant advantage for incumbents over non-bank platforms. However, recent regulatory initiatives signal increasing openness to fintech. "Regulatory sandboxes and open banking initiatives indicate a shift in authorities' willingness to encourage innovation and competition," Megan Fox, a Moody's assistant vice president-analyst and co-author of the report says.
Competitors may opt to avoid regulatory barriers by relying on a bank partnership to satisfy regulation. In this disruptive scenario, banks would remain subject to all regulatory requirements, while "white labeling" their products, and big tech partners will hold the key customer relationships and avoid regulatory barriers.
The report "Fintech -- Global: Bank of the Future: Innovative incumbents will thrive; laggards will be disrupted," is available to Moody's subscribers at http://www.moodys.com /viewresearchdoc.aspx?docid=PBC_1116770.
A podcast featuring highlights of this report can be accessed at   www.moodys.com /bankfuturepodcast. This is the first in a global series of research from Moody's examining Finance of the Future.

urn:contentItem:5S6Y-C6F1-DYG2-R46V-00000-00Moody's: Innovative and Agile Leaders Will Harness Technology to Shape the Bank of the Future2018-04-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisMoody's: Innovative and Agile Leaders Will Harness Technology to Shape the Bank of the FutureTargeted News ServiceNEW YORK

Moody's Investors Service, a credit ratings, research, tools and analysis provider, issued the following news release:

Digital innovation in financial services is placing a premium on efficiency and opening up competition that will continue to drive disruption across banking business segments, including payments, lending, capital markets and wealth management, Moody's Investors Service says in a new report.

Agile incumbent banks, that consistently assert digital leadership, will thrive and prosper, while laggard banks that lack the vision or resources to develop competitive digital strategies will be disrupted. Aging legacy financial platforms have created opportunities for new nimble entrants to capture a portion of banks' profits by offering more customer-focused, responsive and efficient channels.

Moody's says the bank of the future will cater to high and rapidly evolving customer expectations by harnessing key enabling technologies, leveraging increasingly mature and dependable digital distribution channels, and applying these tools across multiple businesses and product segments. Customers will gravitate to providers that best meet their demands for convenience, personalization and affordability, with privacy and data security a growing competitive differentiator. Amid the shifts in technology and consumer demand, competition will stiffen among banks, big technology companies and small fintechs.

"In the face of these threats, successful incumbent banks will be those that, either on their own or in collaboration with others, pursue aggressive digital transformation to become more efficient and responsive to evolving customer demands," Fadi Abdel Massih, a Moody's analyst and co-author of the report says. "Disintermediation of the customer relationship would be a threat to this business model if it ends up reducing banks' pricing power by transforming them into providers of a 'back-office' balance sheet for customer-facing apps/businesses."

Digitization will offer efficiency enhancement opportunities for incumbent banks through the optimization of branch networks, data collection, analysis and reporting process but not without high initial investment.

To date, regulatory requirements have been a moat protecting incumbents. The traditional, more regulated banking model -- reliant on cheap, sticky deposits -- retains a significant advantage for incumbents over non-bank platforms. However, recent regulatory initiatives signal increasing openness to fintech. "Regulatory sandboxes and open banking initiatives indicate a shift in authorities' willingness to encourage innovation and competition," Megan Fox, a Moody's assistant vice president-analyst and co-author of the report says.

Competitors may opt to avoid regulatory barriers by relying on a bank partnership to satisfy regulation. In this disruptive scenario, banks would remain subject to all regulatory requirements, while "white labeling" their products, and big tech partners will hold the key customer relationships and avoid regulatory barriers.

The report "Fintech -- Global: Bank of the Future: Innovative incumbents will thrive; laggards will be disrupted," is available to Moody's subscribers at http://www.moodys.com/viewresearchdoc.aspx?docid=PBC_1116770.

A podcast featuring highlights of this report can be accessed at www.moodys.com/bankfuturepodcast. This is the first in a global series of research from Moody's examining Finance of the Future.

urn:contentItem:5TGB-3GH1-J9XT-P0T4-00000-00Moody's kicks off annual banking conference for Asia Pacific2018-10-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisMoody's kicks off annual banking conference for Asia Pacific

New York City: Moody's Investors Service has issued the following news release: Moody's Investors Service says that the banking sector globally is set to undergo a long-term and structural evolution, driven by how technological advances are creating both new challenges and opportunities in a variety of areas. The conclusions are part of this year's Moody's annual banking conference. The event has so far been held in Zurich (2 October) and Singapore (3 October), and further sessions are scheduled for Hong Kong (10 October), Tokyo (16 October) and Beijing (24 October) in Asia Pacific, and Milan (5 October), Paris (9 October), London (11 October), and Frankfurt (18 October) in Europe.

Another key focus of the conference is the impact of the macro-environment -- which now includes rising interest rates and increasing trade tensions -- on the banking sector. With technological innovation, which is the basis of the conference's Bank of the Future presentation and discussion, Moody's analysts will discuss the impact of digital transformation on banks in four main areas: customer expectations; competition and business models; cost structure and infrastructure; and regulation. "In this environment, rapidly changing customer expectations will also drive digital innovations, while competition will stiffen and change focus along with shifts in technology and consumer demand," says Eugene Tarzimanov, a Moody's Vice President and Senior Credit Officer. "Furthermore, infrastructure will act as the foundation for financial innovation, but regulatory requirements will protect the position of incumbents," says Tarzimanov. The specific topics for presentation and discussion for each of the four conference are: • How the changing interest rate environment challenges the financial sector • Bank of the future • Big tech's shift to banking "On the changes in the interest rate environment globally, Moody's notes that the macro-environment is becoming more challenging with trade tensions a clear risk," says Tarzimanov. "Rising interest rates pose challenges for corporates and banks in emerging markets, but banks are generally well positioned to withstand emerging headwinds due to stronger capital and liquidity buffers," says Tarzimanov. In each location, in addition to these global themes, senior Moody's analysts joined by leading industry participants will discuss issues specific to their own locations. In the case of Hong Kong and Beijing, the conference will examine the outlook for Chinese Banks, and in Singapore the outlook for ASEAN and Indian banks. Meanwhile, the Tokyo conference will also look at the outlook for Japanese banks. This publication does not announce a credit rating action. For any credit ratings referenced in this publication, please see the ratings tab on the issuer/entity page on www.moodys.com for the most updated credit rating action information and rating history.

urn:contentItem:5W94-DFH1-J9XT-P06V-00000-00Moody's says that a DOJ antitrust probe into Alphabet's Google business would be credit negative2019-06-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisMoody's says that a DOJ antitrust probe into Alphabet's Google business would be credit negative

New York City: Moody's Investors Srvice has issued the following news release: Moody's Investors Service says that media reports stating that the Justice Department's (DOJ) preparation for a potential launch of an investigation into the business practices and market position of Alphabet Inc.'s (Aa2; stable outlook) Google and the House Judiciary Committee's separate antitrust investigation into big tech's market dominance more broadly are credit negative for Google's parent Alphabet Inc., but at this time there is no impact on its Aa2 long-term debt rating, Prime-1 short term credit rating or stable outlook. Moody's believes that regulation is and has always been the primary risk and key constraint to Alphabet's credit profile, and is already incorporated into its Aa2 long-term debt ratings. However, some of that risk emerged first from more stringent European anticompetitive scrutiny, increased regulation and over $9bn in fines since 2016. However, Google was left largely untouched in the US. The company's most serious antitrust threat in the US was dropped by the FTC in 2013 and left the company unscathed.

The broad and bipartisan shift in tone from US regulators, lawmakers and presidential candidates poses a larger risk for the company. The company is exposed to large international fines. However, there are no US federal government fines for civil monopolization violations, and our most important fundamental concern is whether regulation or actions imposed on the company materially and permanently alter its business model such that its leading positions, business diversity and profitability are significantly constrained and reduced. We believe that any potential probes or formal investigations will include long and labored processes and even if the most aggressive negative outcomes are assumed, they would likely be subject to legal actions and appeals which would result in long implementation delays. We believe that Alphabet is well conditioned for such battles and has so far effectively warded off actions that would kindle our major concerns. Google's profitable products are largely free to consumers, though their online activities are tracked, and compiled data about these online activities are used by advertisers to target consumers with greater relevancy. As there are only media reports so far, we presently believe that negative actions and rulings that would materially impact Alphabet's credit standing, remain a low probability. However, we note that in the event that an adverse outcome requires Google to modify its business model to limit or shrink its market position in its flagship search or advertising businesses, there would be significant implications for the company's credit standing given that about 85% of the company's revenues are generated from advertising and 83% of its advertising revenue is generated from its own websites. Notwithstanding the risk posed by the heightened antitrust scrutiny, Alphabet maintains an extremely strong balance sheet with over $113 billion in cash and short-term investments against $19.9 billion in Moody's adjusted debt at March 31 (includes $7.6 billion transition tax payable and $8.2 billion in operating leases). Moreover, we expect the company to generate over $30 billion of free cash flow in 2019, some of which can be earmarked for any potential international fines without compromising the company's ability to invest in growth and innovation or materially altering its pristine liquidity. Media reports are stating that the DOJ's investigation remains in its early stage and no formal investigation has commenced. However, the political environment is dynamic and as previously mentioned, these types of investigations and subsequent judicial appeals are often lengthy, reducing the likelihood of any near-term impact to Alphabet's credit profile. Alphabet is the holding company for Google, which includes its advertising business and its "Other Revenue" (Google Play, Google Cloud, Hardware, YouTube subscriptions) and "Other Bets" subsidiaries. Google is the world's leading Internet search engine, and it maintains an index of websites and other online content for users, advertisers, Google network members, and other content providers. This publication does not announce a credit rating action. For any credit ratings referenced in this publication, please see the ratings tab on the issuer/entity page on www.moodys.com for the most updated credit rating action information and rating history.

urn:contentItem:5T7S-MMW1-JBHT-D373-00000-00Moonves Steps Down; Tax Cuts 2.0; Trade Tensions; Declassifying FISA Documents; Bruce Ohr Grilled Over Steele Dossier Back In August; Florence Gains Strength; Ancient Roman Coins Found; Gretzky Names Global Ambassador Of China's Only Professional Hockey Team2018-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisMoonves Steps Down; Tax Cuts 2.0; Trade Tensions; Declassifying FISA Documents; Bruce Ohr Grilled Over Steele Dossier Back In August; Florence Gains Strength; Ancient Roman Coins Found; Gretzky Names Global Ambassador Of China's Only Professional Hockey TeamLanhamFULL TEXT

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: We're going to say happy Monday to Maria Bartiromo. MORNINGS WITH MARIA starts now.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hi there ladies, happy Monday to you and thanks so much. Good morning everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo, happy Monday. It is Monday, September 10th. Your top stories right now just before 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Moonves is out, the CBS CEO is stepping down as more sexual misconduct charges surfaced. The turmoil throwing a possible wrench into the CBS- Viacom merger, we've got all the details there. Shari Redstone is winning.

Futures this morning showing the markets will open higher, take a look. The Dow Industrials set to be up better than 70 points this morning. NASDAQ also strong this morning, up about 36, that's one half of one percent.

This after the major market indices closed lower on Friday, pretty much across the board. Dow Industrials gave up a third of a percent for the 79- point selloff. NASDAQ was down a quarter of a percent as well as the S&P500.

In Europe this morning take a look at the action and we do see money move in to stocks, fractional moves across the board but nonetheless in positive territory.

Asian markets overnight mixed, as you can see worst performer was in Hong Kong, Hang Seng Index down one and a third percent, China, Shanghai Composite down one and a quarter percent.

Peril in Paris to report, seven people have been injured this morning in a knife attack in the City of Lights. We've got the very latest this morning.

Sour Apple, the House fit jobs built says that China tariffs will affect its pricing. What the president says the easy fix could be. Apple shares are down a fraction this morning.

And bang for your buck, a new report has a list of the most valuable college degrees, the top spot may surprise you.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning and joining me to break it all down, our own Susan Li joining the panel this morning. The CEO and Managing Partner of Rosecliff Mike Murphy is here. And Pollster and the President of Maslansky & Partners Lee Carter. Good morning.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Good morning. It's great to be here.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO & MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF: Happy Monday.

BARTIROMO: And to you. We've got the Bob Lighthizer, the trade minister in Europe this morning talking about tariffs, perhaps probably doing a deal. Are the markets still concerned Susan about these tariffs and the (INAUDIBLE)

LI: Absolutely. I mean, $200 billion could go to --

BARTIROMO: On China.

LI: -- $207 billion for -- on China. We don't have a new NAFTA yet and I think you're seeing an overhang in the Asian market, I was telling you the story right now especially with Apple and do they ship production out of China under pressure for the U.S. president, I think trade is pretty much the impact that we're seeing globally at this point.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I feel like the markets in the U.S. have giving this president a break and watching to see his negotiating. I mean otherwise I think the market will be a lot -- a lot lower, don't you think?

MURPHY: I think professional traders Maria are looking past the headlines and they're looking at the underlying fundamentals and what is clearly an improving economy. So, a lot of talk to about the Fed and the Fed raising rates.

But I think the underlying fact that the economy is good, getting better is what's keeping the market up at these -- at these levels. So any trade deal moves us to new high.

BARTIROMO: We had a good jobs number on Friday, of course, and we've got more data this week. Meanwhile, the campaign trail is heating up. President Obama on the campaign trail Lee, how's that going?

CARTER: You know, it's been really interesting to watch because there's been a lot of criticism obviously of him coming out on the right. On the other hand, this is the first time that we've seen something the left come out and not be totally hysterical.

He's trying to get people activated and hopeful again. He's reengaging in some of that rhetoric and you're seeing a lot of people feeling good about it. But what really I think I'm seeing in this is that there's a huge vacuum in leadership on the Democratic Party that he has to come back out and he's feeling a void that really has been felt. So, I think that the democrats need them and that's not good for them.

BARTIROMO: Yes. True. The republicans are pushing back on some of his ideas in terms of how this economy is doing and where it started and all of that. We'll talk about that.

Coming up this morning joining the conversation, White House Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley is here. Retired U.S. Army Lieutenant Colonel, former Congressman Allen West joins us, along with former Hillary for America Senior Advisor, Democratic Strategist Adrienne Elrod back with us this morning. And Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano.

Don't miss a moment of it, we got a big three hours coming up. But our top story right now, a major media shakeup to report, CBS had Les Moonves is stepping down amid sexual misconduct allegations.

The size of Moonves' exit package will depend on whether he is found guilty of any wrong doing stemming from CBS's internal investigations into the matter. Susan Li, does this affect the CBS going forward in terms of more deals with them?

LI: Well more deals that's been put off because they have new six board members and part of this exit plan means that Viacom-CBS re-merger, that won't happen for two more years.

But then there's not going to be a sale of CBS as well and I think that's going to pressure the shares because I think in the market had anticipated there might have been some sort of shares -- sales to somebody but at this point it looks like that's been put off with this Les Moonves departure.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Sumner Redstone's daughter, Shari Redstone and Les Moonves have been going at it in terms of where this company goes next. Impact on the stock Mike?

BARTIROMO: So, what would you say in terms of what we could see next? I mean, we know that the President has successfully dealt with Mexico but we're waiting to see if Canada follows suit and you've got colleagues in Europe this morning dealing with the Europeans. What can you tell us?

GIDLEY: Well, look, I mean the President had some breakthroughs with President Juncker here at the White House with the E.U., he's had breakthroughs with Mexico, he's dealing with Canada as we speak. China get that deal done as well, you know, we came do a bilateral agreement with Mexico. The President has said many times, he wants Canada in that deal but he wants the deal to be fair for Americans.

And if it's not going to be and Canada does not want to play ball then they'll have to get it alone and the President will join with Mexico and they'll keep that deal in place. He wants more people brought to the table, he wants to trade barriers eliminated, he want some gone. He believes our farmers, our workers can compete against anybody around the globe. The problem is we've got to have those tariffs come down.

And the President is going to fight for the Americans -- and the American workers and American businesses to make sure that happens.

BARTIROMO: So, are you expecting another deal to be announced before the midterm elections, Hogan?

GIDLEY: I'm not sure. You know, the President has said it's close, I don't want to guess or pontificate on what close means. But the President in all of those trade deals and those negotiations, he wants them to be pro-American. He understands other countries have to success too. He's not anti-Mexico or anti-Canada. In fact, he says on every occasion he can that he wants them to succeed too.

But it can't be at the cost of the American people, and that's what he's here to protect.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about this potential looming government shutdown if that's still the case. The journal this morning is reporting Congressional leaders are expected to secure a deal today on three separate spending bills avoiding a partial government shutdown by the end of the month. Will the President get the funding for the border wall and if the funding is not in this upcoming budget end of September, do you think that hurts Republicans going into the midterms?

GIDLEY: Look, I think it hurts all Americans when our country isn't safe and that's what this President swore an oath to protect the American people first and foremost. He wants border security, he's talked about how he wants that whether it'd be a border wall, whether it's ending chain migration and other pillars that he's discussed in the past. Democrats chose to shut the government down.

And they chose actually quite frankly to stand up for hundreds of thousands of people who are here illegally and unlawfully as opposed to hundreds of millions of Americans citizens. That's what blows my mind. It's not worry about Democrat versus Republican, it's about the American people. The President has promised to protect them and he wants Congress to come to the table to provide the funding to do that.

Right now we have a porous border; it's the worst immigration laws in the world. He's made that quite clear. People are poring across the border. You have drug lords, child trafficking, human trafficking coming across this border into this country. It's a very dangerous situation and Democrats don't want to solve it. The President wants a lasting solution and will fight with Congress to get it.

BARTIROMO: Do Republicans want to solve it? I mean, do you think Republicans are onboard with this President in terms of making sure the money is there is to secure the borders?

GIDLEY: They sure seem like they are, they talk about it incessantly on the campaign trail, the proof that was n the pudding, you got to put the money out in order to protect the American people. The President ran on that, he was elected on that. And I believe quite frankly a lot of Republicans were elected on that too. So, hopefully they join with this President to protect the American people because that's what this is all about.

It's not about limiting numbers or some crazy scheme to keep people out of this country. The President says he loves immigration, he just wants it to be fair, he wants it to be reasonable, he wants it to protect American citizens but he also wants it to be based on merit, he wants people to come to this country. If they want to come here he wants them to assimilate.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

GIDLEY: Learn language but contribute to society and not be a drain on it.

BARTIROMO: But do you think the rhetoric coming out of the President's office these days is a little less in terms of we will shut the government down if we don't have funding for the border wall. If the money is not there, the President last week when he was in Montana spoke to Pete Hegseth sounded more realistic in terms of, look, we don't want to shut it down right before the midterm elections. Is that what you're hearing from the President now?

GIDLEY: Well, look, I was standing next to him in that interview and the subsequent one on the plane ride home and he said listen, I don't want to shut down to happen.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GIDLEY: But I'm willing to fight and do what it takes politically to protect the American people.

BARTIROMO: So no shutdown?

GIDLEY: Well, I don't know what form that's going to take. I just know the President is going to push to protect the American people regardless. It's not necessarily about a shutdown before the midterm or afterwards, it's about coming up in a lasting solution, that's what he wants.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about the Intel investigations into what took place in the 2016 election year, the White House is expected now people talking about the President to declassify documents related to the government surveillance of former aide Carter Page and more on what DOJ official Bruce Ohr knew regarding ties to the Steele dossier. (END VIDEO CLIP)
