urn:contentItem:5S3B-X4Y1-JBHT-D374-00000-00More Than 250 Dead in Algerian Military Plane Crash; Theranos Lays Off Most Of Its Remaining Workforce; Speaker Ryan Will Announce He Won't Run Again Today2018-04-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisMore Than 250 Dead in Algerian Military Plane Crash; Theranos Lays Off Most Of Its Remaining Workforce; Speaker Ryan Will Announce He Won't Run Again TodayLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, April 11th. Your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. Global tensions weighing on stocks. Futures are showing losses across the board, they're down about 200 points right now and we can report that all 30 Dow stocks are down premarket. The loss is accelerating in the last hour after President Trump tweeted on Syria saying Russia vows to shoot down any and all missiles fired at Syria. Get ready, Russia, because they will be coming, nice and new and smart.

You shouldn't be partnering with a gas killing animal who kills his own people and enjoys it. More on the rising tensions straight ahead. This comes one day after the Dow climbed more than 400 points, that was following some soothing words from China's President, Xi Jinping, promising an open market and to cut tariffs and auto imports. And of course one of the top winners yesterday, Facebook. Shares seeing their biggest gain in two years as CEO Mark Zuckerberg faced that grilling on ca Capitol Hill over everything from the Cambridge Analytica privacy scandal to possible Russian election interference.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, CEO, FACEBOOK: When you add more rules that companies need to follow, that's something that a larger company like ours inherently just has the resources to go do and that might just be harder for a smaller company getting started to be able to comply with. There are real challenges that we face around content and privacy.

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: If we're counting on Facebook to regulate itself, we're going to fail.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Zuckerberg returns to Capitol Hill this morning where he'll testify before house lawmakers. He kept his cool yesterday and didn't make the face when asked stupid questions by those Senators that everybody at home watching did. Fox Business will bring you that live coverage starting at 10:00 a.m. Eastern. Tragedy in Algeria, the details after a military plane crashes, killing at least 250 people. Nunes fighting back, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee calls out Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein and FBI Director Christopher Wray over the justification for the Russia probe. The initial justification, where is the full memo? The latest on the tensions in the Capitol ahead and the deadline which is today.

Investors tuning into Spotify in its first week of trading. Now the company is looking to keep up that success. The big plans for your listening habits ahead. And talk about a royal snub, both President Trump and former President Barack Obama will not be invite ted to the upcoming royal wedding. Why Harry and Meghan left the leader of the free world and the last leader of the free world off the exclusive invite list. Here to break it all down with me, CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell, Fox Business Network's Connell McShane and former Republican presidential candidate, Fox News Contributor Herman Cain.

HERMAN CAIN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Happy to be here.

MCDOWELL: Great to see you.

CAIN: Thank you.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN ANCHOR: Didn't get invited either to the wedding?

CAIN: No. I didn't get my invitation to the wedding.

MCDOWELL: We have better things to do. I think.

CAIN: Yes, we do.

MCDOWELL: I think we all have better things to do. And I want to just point out, we have the futures board up right now, we have more than 200 point loss in the Dow futures. That's off its lows in the morning. But all 30 Dow stocks are in the red and it is markets. We seem to shift from day-to-day, from one worry to another. So what is it? Lindsey Bell is going to weigh in on that because again it was interest rates and inflation, inflation data out at the bottom of the hour on the consumer price index. Interest rates, inflation and the Federal Reserve and then it was to trade war with China, tariffs and now it's about Syria. So again, those are the three -- those are the three risks to the market that the Wall Street Journal pointed out at the very beginning of t this year, the Federal Reserve and monetary policy, a trade war initiated by the White House and then geopolitical problems.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Right. And then we also have the tech regulation which goes with the Facebook theme as well. But I think the first issue that you mentioned it the Fed and that has been the biggest concern. I think not a lot of people have been talking about it, is that the Fed is -- they are shrinking their balance sheet. They are selling. We were talking about this --

MCDOWELL: I raised my hand because I talk about it nonstop. I talk about it to my parents and they're sick of it.

BELL: Yes. And so, you know, I think that a lot if a lot of these issues came up a year ago and the Fed is still in the market and still supporting risk assets, you might not have seen these big reactions and snaps in the stock market to these news points.

MCSHANE: Because it's so headline-driven to your point -- I mean, that's a good point because we sometimes have to take a step back and say what are the broader trends, what are the things we should be walking over six months or a year but now it's six minutes. I mean, and now it's a presidential tweet in the morning about Syria that moves the market, tomorrow it might be something else.

MCDOWELL: And your folks in the Republican Party need to stop spending so much (INAUDIBLE) on money.

CAIN: I'm a conservative. I vote Republican. Let's get that straight. Here's the thing about the market. Don't forget. It's very complex and there are a lot of moving parts. So when one part moves you've got some other parts that are going to react. It's still trying to find its balance this early in the administration. It's only been a year. Secondly, you've got a lot of short-term investors that are reacting to everything in the news.

MCDOWELL: And reaction we will get today to Mark Zuckerberg's testimony, his second day on Capitol Hill, this after he faced questions from Senators for about five hours yesterday. Deirdre Bolton, I love watching her down there. She is still on Capitol Hill. Hey, Deirdre.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FBN ANCHOR: Hey, Dagen. Well, you said it. This is part of the 48 hours that the founder, CEO, and chairman of Facebook Mark Zuckerberg is facing. He talked about those five hours of questioning yesterday from Senators. Today, more to come. The House Energy and Commerce Committee members are going to be questioning Mr. Zuckerberg. So yesterday there were a few intense exchanges, let's call them that. Here's one of the more colorful ones from Senator John Kennedy from Louisiana.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. JOHN KENNEDY (R), LOUISIANA: Your user agreement sucks. The purpose of that user agreement is to cover Facebook's rear end. It's not to inform your users about their rights. Now you know that and I know that. I'm going to suggest to you that you go back home and rewrite it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: All right, Dagen. So that had a little comedic relief there, especially for the crowd. Some of the Senators were more on point about business topics. You had Senator Lindsey Graham saying is Facebook a monopoly and he used an analogy with a car manufacturer saying, listen, if a car doesn't work that well consumers have other choices for car models and, therefore, can challenge if you're basically creating a substandard product. So Mark Zuckerberg squirmed a little on that one, one of the other highlight was Senator Dick Durbin saying, oh, well, I care about privacy, where did you stay? Where are you staying this week? What's your hotel address? Who have you message? Just underlining this difference between personal privacy and what is open to the public. So more to come, Dagen. We'll be on it. In the meantime, back to you.

MCDOWELL: I can't wait for that, Deirdre. Deirdre Bolton down in Washington. Was that a bomb-sniffing dog that was barking? Could you hear it?

BOLTON: I think so. We have a lot of things going on here, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: There was someone in a troll costume yesterday, right?

BOLTON: Yes, yes, that was classic.

MCDOWELL: So, Connell tweeted about it, he said that was the highlight of the day.

BOLTON: You know, she stood out, she stood out and were protester as well, saying stop stealing corporate data, the colored pink ladies. You know, we've had a lot of fun here, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Deirdre, thank you for that. Deirdre Bolton in the D.C. for us. And joining us now is Republican Texas Congressman, House Financial Service Committee Chairman, Jeb Hensarling. Your reaction to the testimony by Mark Zuckerberg yesterday, what you would like to hear from him today?

REP. JEB HENSARLING (R), TEXAS, CHAIRMAN, HOUSE FINANCIAL SERVICE COMMITTEE: Well, it won't be before my committee. We have another hearing with the acting director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. But again, I think people need to know exactly what privacy rights should they be able to expect. I listened to the exchange with Senator Kennedy which besides being -- adding a little levity, my guess is greater clarity needs to be provided.

I mean, too many of these privacy agreements are written in legal ease, they're voluminous and they need to be succinct and written in English and people have to make decision about how much of their privacy do they want to be shared -- have shared. And so, I think the hearings will be good. I think it illuminate these issues going forward and again, we're going to be kind of be busy doing our own thing in the Financial Services Committee but I'll keep an extra ear open for what's going on down the hall.

MCDOWELL: Well, you mentioned the hearing with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau director, -- acting director, Mick Mulvaney. This actually does dovetail with the Facebook hearing because we set up this protection bureau after the financial crisis. What the heck have they been doing? Because again, protecting data on Facebook not happening. Protecting customers at Wells Fargo, well, that was uncovered by the L.A. Times. What do you want to hear from Mick Mulvaney today?

HENSARLING: Well, again, you well pointed out, you wonder what's been going on at Wells Fargo. I mean, clearly all kinds of problems. I mean, I know they have new management in place but it seems like every single day another shoe is dropping from something happening under the old management. And you wonder why didn't we create an entire new agency that supposedly had employees embedded in the job and they still didn't figure it out.

There's a couple different problems with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. It's -- remains the most unaccountable, most powerful Federal agency in the history of the Republic. That was true under Richard Cordray, an Obama appointee . It's true under Mulvaney, a Republican- appointee. They're just not accountable. There's no checks and balances. They take their money straight from the Fed. They're not on the appropriations process.

The President can only fire the head of the CFPB for cause. The courts and there's something called the Chevron deference have to basically put their thumb on the scale in favor of the CFPB. And then finally, there's not even a them at the CFPB, there's only a him, one person can basically wake up on the wrong side of the morning and outlaw any credit card, checking account or mortgage he wants to.

That is fundamentally in opposition to the American foundational value of checks and balances and frankly, a lot of people are being denied due process. They are Congress, prosecutor (INAUDIBLE) judge, jury, all rolled into one which our founders in the Federalist papers, I think it was Federalist 47, Madison, would have called the very definition of tyranny. So number one, they're unaccountable. Number two, they're hurting consumers.

MCDOWELL: Right.

HENSARLING: Free checking has been cut in half at banks. There are 15 percent fewer credit cards that cost 200 basis points more. It's much harder for middle income Americans to find mortgages. And so these are the problems we have to get to.

MCDOWELL: Congressman, Herman Cain has a question.

HENSARLING: Sure.

CAIN: One of the things that I have heard from small bankers is that the initial roll-out of CFP --Consumer Protection Agency, a lot of small banks were put out of business. We have heard that the attempts now are to roll back some of those regulations to make it easier for small banks to survive. Is that in the version you are working on?

HENSARLING: Well, absolutely. And this is not fake news, Herman. A lot of banks and credit unions have gone out of business and a lot of them because of Dodd-Frank large and the CFPB in specific. And so the CFPB sets the standards and they roll downhill. And the big banks they have the resources to handle this regulatory load but not the smaller banks. And so small bank as you probably know lend to small businesses and without that credit channel a lot of small businesses won't be formed. We don't know where the next godfather's pizza will come from, if we're losing our small community banks. So, there is legislation that has come out to of the House, legislation that has come out of the Senate to really help kind of our community banks. I hope we're going to come together, negotiate a package soon that we can support because the community banks are just dying on the vine.

MCDOWELL: Congressman, I do want to get your reaction to these strong words on Syria and Russia from President Trump this morning. He's ramping up the rhetoric as he mulls a possible missile strike, missile strikes against Bashar al Assad after that suspected chemical attack. Here is just some of what he tweeted earlier. Russia vows to shoot down any in all missiles fired at Syria. Get ready, Russia, because they will be coming, nice new and smart. It shouldn't be partnered with a gas-killing animal, he kills his own people and enjoys it. It looks like the President has made his decision. What's your reaction to this and partners, any allies who act alongside us in this effort?

HENSARLING: Well, it's absolutely outrageous that we still in the 21st century are seeing the use of chemical weapons. I mean, they cannot be allowed to do this. And we know that the President's predecessor, President Obama infamously drew his red line in the sand and then he let them cross it. And so I think what we're hearing from this president is you're not going to be allowed to cross that line. We are not going to introduce chemical weapons and allow them to be used on your own people. They are absolutely horrific and atrocious. And so, listen, I'm not commander-in-chief. He's commander-in-chief. But Syria has to get the word, Russia has to get the word. I hope that, again, this will be measured. Steps have to be taken that are necessary to ensure this does not happen again.

MCDOWELL: Congressman, Jeff Hensarling, thank you so much for being here.

HENSARLING: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Breaking news. A plane crash killing more than 250 people in Algeria. Cheryl Casone has the details. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FBN ANCHOR: That's right, Dagen. An Algerian military jet crashed near the country's capital killing at least 257 people. The transport plane filled with soldiers and their families came down near a military base shortly after takeoff. It's not clear what caused this crash but it is the worst plane crash in Algeria since 2003 when an Air Algerie jet went down. That crash killed 102.

Well, Theranos is making some major job cuts. Reports say the blood- testing firm is laying off almost everyone that works there in an effort to keep the company afloat and avoid bankruptcy. The layoff chopped company's the workforce from 125 to about two dozen. That is way down from 2015 when they had about 800 people there. Their founder and CEO Elizabeth Holmes has announced the staffing changes near a month after settling civil fraud charge was the FCC which forced her to give up voting control over her own company and pay a $500,000 fine.

Well, John Boehner, remember him? He is getting involved in the rapidly expanding U.S. marijuana industry. The former Speaker of the House has joined the advisory board of Acreage Holdings. The company grows and sells marijuana in 11 states. Boehner, a Republican went on the record nine years ago saying he was opposed to legalizing pot. But now he says that his attitude towards it has changed like that of many Americans out there. And at least two-thirds of Americans want pot legalized according to Gallup survey.

And then there is this. The royal wedding just over a month away and the invitations have been sent out. Notable names missing from the guest list is former President Obama, who is friends with Prince Harry. President Trump will also be missing from the crowd when harry ties the knot with the next member of the royal family, American actress Meghan Markle. Kensington Palace recently announced that no politicians will be receiving an invite to the event and that includes, yes, this lady, U.K. Prime Minister, Theresa May. Tough invites if you can get it. All right. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Do you really want to go if Anna Wintour is going to be there though. I'm just saying. I'm guessing that she's going to be invited potentially, so, again, I don't want to belong to any club that would have me as a member. That's Groucho Marx.

MCSHANE: That's good. I mean, John Boehner in the pot company? I guess let us let that go.

CAIN: Was he getting paid (INAUDIBLE) it makes a difference if he's getting a little skin in the game from being an advisory board member.

MCSHANE: But there's so many jokes.

BELL: He's getting older from marijuana.

CAIN: Yes. But he is still smoking.

MCDOWELL: Cigarettes. He was a cigarette smoker.

CAIN: I know. But now, you know, he may be making an upgrade to marijuana, who knows?

MCDOWELL: It's legal in some states.

CAIN: Check out the statistics in Colorado before people jump on the bandwagon. That's all I'm saying.

MCDOWELL: What statistics, about the --

CAIN: About the impact of legalizing marijuana in the state.

MCDOWELL: Workplace productivity.

CAIN: Workplace productivity, more homelessness, seriously. They haven't put out all the statistics, but that's what's happening in Colorado.

MCDOWELL: There you go.

CAIN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Herman, I love having you here.

CAIN: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Amazon is under fire. Still we're breaking down a shocking report which outlines how the retail giant avoided paying millions of dollars in taxes last year. Plus the FTC weighing in on those warranty void if removed stickers. What the Consumer Protection Agency is telling shoppers, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: We have breaking news this morning. Axios is reporting that Speaker of the House Paul Ryan is expected to announce that he will not run for re-election in November. Maria Bartiromo when she interviewed Paul Ryan in mid-February 13th, asked him about him running for re-election. I believe his response was something to the effect I need to talk to my wife about it. This is something I'll discuss with my wife. But again, Axio reporting he will not run again. That means Paul Ryan is leaving certainly Congress, Herman Cain, your reaction.

CAIN: Well, it's a double hit. Because first, he won't be in Congress, and secondly he won't be speaker. That means the speaker position is going to be a toss-up. And personally I think that the frontrunners are McCarthy and Scalise. Scalise projects more leadership even though you have that unfortunate accident of being shot. It's going to be a scramble for the speaker's position.

MCSHANE: I mean, McCarthy's similar -- I mean, in terms of make-up and in terms of who his allies would be and where his critics would be to Paul Ryan, isn't that fair?

CAIN: That's a fair statement. That's why I say it's going to be a toss- up in terms of who's going to be scrambling to try to get that position.

MCDOWELL: I just feel like from John Boehner to Paul Ryan and it might be less of a point if the Democrats manage to take back the House, then it's - - the job is quite a bit smaller for the Republican leader in the house.

CAIN: Memo to Dagen, they are not going to take back the House. That's just their rhetoric, the Democrats. I feel very strongly about that. I don't feel strongly about a lot of things. They're not going to take back control of the House.

MCDOWELL: They're raising an awful lot of money, Herman.

CAIN: Yes. They tried to buy an election in Georgia with $30 million against $8 million and the Republican won. Why? Because we were able to energize the Republican voters to get out. Money couldn't buy that seat. This is the --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: You run a bad candidate who runs a bad campaign like what happened in Pennsylvania and the Democrats win.

CAIN: That's a different story.

MCSHANE: Do you think Paul Ryan being out energizes the -- if this is true, would energize Republican basis?

(CROSSTALK)

CAIN: I don't think -- it would energize the members that are pretty sure they're coming back but not necessarily the voters. The voters have got to be energized with a very strong, very clear Republican message, which they don't have out there right now. The results are on their side with this President. But they have not taken it and crystallized their message.

MCDOWELL: I agree, all over the place, what we say down south. Switching gears. The FTC says it's OK to remove those pesky warranty stickers. Lauren Simonetti has more.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN REPORTER: Hey there. The Federal Trade Commission says these warranty void if removed sticker are B.S. They fired off a letter to six manufacturers -- you've seen those -- of cars, phones and video game consoles. This is what they wrote, "provisions that tie warrantee coverage to the use of particular products or services harm both consumers, who pay more for them, as well as the small businesses who offer competing products. We don't know which companies were warned but think -- Sony think Microsoft as they make many of the products in question."

The FTC says they're breaking the law because a manufacturer can't tell a consumer they can't fix their own stuff or that they can't have a third party fix it. So here's an example. You buy a new Honda. It breaks. You take it to your local mechanic. They can't fix it and you take it back to Honda. The FTC says Honda cannot deny you return because you went to the repair shop first. That thinks to the 1975 (INAUDIBLE) consumers don't know about this. We don't know our rights and many companies exploit that with those no trespassing stamps that we just showed you. So bottom line, do your homework. You can take your stuff back. This applies to Apple iPhones, by the way, if the screen is messed up. Usually a third party is allowed to fix it.

MCSHANE: You just sounded like Lindsey Graham at the hearing yesterday with the whole car example for a second. Which is actually a good example yesterday.

MCDOWELL: Lindsey Graham was pulling -- you know, he was doing that whole southern trick. I'm going to sound stupid but I'm going to catch you, right?

CAIN: It might not be a trick with him. I'm just saying. Wow. I'm just saying it might not be.

MCSHANE: Coming in heavy.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Somebody on Twitter just called you gentleman. Now not so much.

CAIN: Oh, wow. I don't do political correctness. You know that.

MCDOWELL: I love having Herman Cain here. And the message from Lauren as those companies can stick those stickers where the sun don't shine.

SIMONETTI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Thank you.

SIMONETTI: You're welcome.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Coming up. A major test for Mark Zuckerberg. How the Facebook CEO responded to lawmakers grilling him about his company's data scandal, next. Plus Jim Carrey slamming the President again, the backlash over his latest insulting tweet ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Wednesday, April 11th, your top stories at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. Markets are under pressure, we just got the numbers for last month's CPI, the consumer price index hitting the tape. You haven't seen much movement in the Dow Futures right here, right now. The month-over-month top line CPI was down one-tenth of a percent, that was a drop that was unexpected. But if you look at the year-over-year number which is critical, a 2.4 percent gain on the overall number, core CPI excluding food and energy was up 2.1 percent, which is still a pretty hot inflation number considering what we've seen in the last 10 years.

And then we have rising tensions with Syria also weighing on investors in these Markets. Futures extending their slide after President Trump tweeted this earlier: "Russia vows to shoot down any and all missiles fired at Syria. Get ready, Russia, because they will be coming, nice and new and smart. You shouldn't be partners with a gas-killing animal who kills his own people and enjoys it."

Checking the global market action, in Europe, we have losses across the board. More than a one percent loss on the DAX in Germany. And in Asia overnight, those markets already closed for the day, we had some mixed markets.

Facebook not the only tech giant under fire. New questions over Amazon and its tax practices. We take a closer look ahead. And Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, the CEO, facing questions over bias against conservatives. We have viral stars Diamond and Silk reacting to the hearing later this hour.

And then there's deadline day, the FBI and Justice Department have until today to turn over the unredacted memo that led to the Russia investigation. The initial two-page electronic memo, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes threatening legal action if law enforcement does not comply. And is this the end? Is it coming for Robert Mueller? The White House weighing in on the special counsel and his future.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: I know a number of individuals in the legal community and including at the Department of Justice that he has the power to do so. We've been advised that the President certainly has the power to make that decision.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We're looking at the fallout from those comments. And then Jim Carrey, the so-called artist, taking aim at President Trump and Putin with his latest piece of artwork. The backlash ahead. And investors tuning into Spotify in its first week of trading. Now, the company is looking to keep up the success. The big plans for your listening habits. But first, are special counsel Robert Mueller's days numbered? Blake Burman joins us from the White House with a lot more. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Hi, there, Dagen, good morning to you. After President Trump openly mused here at the White House on Monday that some people, he says, are telling him that he should fire Robert Mueller. The White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders said yesterday that they do believe the President have that power.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDERS: I know a number of individuals in the legal community and including at the Department of Justice that he has the power to do so, but I don't have any further announcements on --

REPORTER: But it is -- they told me (INAUDIBLE) they said it's Rod Rosenstein who oversees the special counsel, only he has the power to fire the special counsel.

SANDER: Again, we've been advised that the President certainly has the power to make that decision. I can't go anything beyond that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Democrats and even several Republicans on Capitol Hill though are calling for the special counsel to be protected. While the top Republican on the House Intelligence Committee has his sights set elsewhere. Congressman Devin Nunes saying last night that if he does not get an unredacted version of the document that he says started the Russia investigation, then he wants the head of the FBI and the number two at the DOJ to lose their jobs.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R), CALIFORNIA, CHAIRMAN, HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: I'll just tell you that we're not going to just hold in contempt. We will have a plan to hold in contempt and to impeach.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: To impeach Christopher Wray?

NUNES: Absolutely.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Rod Rosenstein?

NUNES: We're not -- we're not messing around here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: In a tweet earlier this morning, President Trump said that there was, "no collusion or obstruction other than I fight back. So now they do the unthinkable and raid a lawyer's office for information. Bad!" Of course, though, Dagen, he is referring to the raid of Michael Cohen, the President's personal attorney. President Trump had described that earlier this week as a, quote, attack on our country. In a harsh rebuke yesterday on the Senate floor, Chuck Schumer described that assertion as a, quote, disgrace. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Blake Burman, thank you for the reporting, as always. Blake, at the White House for us. Now, on the Capitol Hill, Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg set to be grilled by House lawmakers today. This, after testifying for roughly five hours before some skeptical Senators who demanded answers about how the social media company allowed Cambridge Analytica to misuse the personal data of up to 87 million Facebook users.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. DICK DURBIN (D), ILLINOIS: Mr. Zuckerberg, would you be comfortable sharing with us the name of the hotel you stayed in last night?

ZUCKERBERG: No.

(LAUGHTER)

DURBIN: If you've messaged anybody this week, would you share with us the names of the people you've messaged?

ZUCKERBERG: Senator, no, I would probably not choose to do that publicly here.

DURBIN: I think that may be what this is all about, your right to privacy, the limits of your right to privacy, and how much you give away in modern America in the name of, quote, connecting people around the world.

KENNEDY: Here's what everybody's been trying to tell you today. And I say this gently. Your user agreement sucks. You spot me 75 I.Q. points. If I can figure it out, you can figure it out. The purpose of the user agreement is to cover Facebook's rear end, it's not to inform your users about their rights.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining me now is Professor of Marketing at NYU Stern School of Business, author of "The Four: The Hidden DNA of Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google," Scott Galloway. Scott, your take on Zuckerberg's performance yesterday?

SCOTT GALLOWAY, PROFESSOR OF MARKETING, NYU STERN SCHOOL OF BUSINESS: It was remarkable on how unremarkable it was. He's -- you know, he's the winner here because the bottomline is he didn't screw up. There was a couple of good sound bites there. But it's nothing -- there was no real moment. And D.C. is the big looser. You think 55 adults would have gotten in a room and said we can't really do anything in four or five minutes each. Who knows technology, raise your hand? Three or four people would have raised their hand out of the 55. And they said, why don't we give each of you more than five minutes so you can actually drill down. It was the format that made this literally a useless exercise.

MCSHANE: That's a really good point.

CAIN: And I agree with you, 200 percent. Absolutely. It was remarkably unremarkable. Most of them knew that going in but it was the opportunity to get five minutes on T.V. That's all it was about. And nothing's going to come out of this, other than Zuckerberg is going to say, well, I'm highly concerned about this whole, you know, screening out conservative stuff. We will take that under advisement.

BELL: Yes, exactly. I think that's a great point, Herman. Scott, what does Mark do after two days of testimony in front of Congress?

GALLOWAY: He goes back to work and he does nothing, and he hires more lobbyists, there's a lot of job (INAUDIBLE) for lobbyists, for Facebook. The bigger -- the folks that are about to go gangster on Facebook right now are in Europe, specifically (INAUDIBLE). Europe in the last week has made more progress if you will or proposed more legislation against Facebook than America has to date. France is talking about taxing them on their top line because Google figured out a way to do $7 billion in revenue in the U.K. and paid $50,000 in taxes. They're talking about regulating Facebook and Twitter as media companies and Britain. Their GDRP is well ahead of anything we're doing. This is a nothing burger here in D.C.

MCSHANE: See, he was told specifically -- his notes, they didn't really leak, they were -- pictures were taken of his notes as they were left out on t he --

MCDOWELL: The A.P. -- right, A.P. took -- the A.P. photographer got a shot of the notes, the prep work that his lawyers had done for him.

MCSHANE: And to Scott's point, he was talking exactly what you were saying, he was instructed if that came up to not really say anything about it, to not come out and say -- which is interesting, well, what would your take would be on this, he was told apparently according to those notes, don't say we're already doing what they're regulating in Europe, that we're already doing that. Apparently, it said that in his notes that he wasn't supposed to come out and say that.

GALLOWAY: Well, there's been a lot of serious lies in big tech. Information wants to be free, that was a lie. We not only comply with the tax laws, we comply with the spirit of the tax laws. That was Tim Cook. The spirit of U.S. tax laws isn't that you issue your I.P. to the isle of man so you can suppress taxes in the U.S., high-tax domain, and increase them in low-tax domains. That's not the spirit of the U.S. tax law. The most recent big lie from big tech was Mark Zuckerberg saying, I'm not sure we shouldn't be regulated. I'd really like to know if the lobbyists in D.C. representing Facebook are running around saying, you know what, we're open to regulation. That is so ridiculous. They will fight tooth and nail any regulation.

CAIN: The only thing that Mark Zuckerberg said that I agree with, if Congress passes regulations, as you know they're going to be too big and too many and it's going to keep any challengers out of the marketplace because a new start-up is going to have a tough time dealing with it. I agree with you. Leave them alone. Let the customers of Facebook decide Facebook's future.

MCDOWELL: It was pretty clear based on the questioning that the last tech gadget some of these senators had bought was a Playskool View-Master, that they don't -- they have no concept of how even cell phones work quick frankly. You brought up taxes. I want to bring up this issue with you, Scott. 15 U.S. corporations including Amazon found ways to avoid taxes on nearly $25 billion in combined profits last year. This is a report from the institute on taxes and economic policy. Amazon received $137 million rebate on $5.4 billion in profits resulting in an effective tax rate of a negative 2-1/2 percent. And Trump -- of course, President Trump's been attacking Amazon for not paying enough in taxes. But again, this kind of goes to your point.

GALLOWAY: We've institutionalized a regressive corporate tax structure. Since 2008, Wal-Mart has paid $64 billion in corporate income tax, Amazon has paid 1.4 billion. This is despite the fact that Amazon has added a value of Wal-Mart to its Market cap in the last three months.

So what we've effectively we -- our tax system around big tech is sort of the Hunger Games. If you survive it and you win, you live a fabulous life and you can avoid taxes. The tax system is so complex and so favors large multinationals that it's basically a transfer of wealth from small domestic and medium-sized companies that only have domestic operations to large multinationals who can afford large tax departments and then can do these sort of -- these unnatural gymnastics to figure out a way to suppress their taxes in high-tax domains. We have -- Amazon is about to view us -- Amazon is about to become the most valuable company in history, and effectively pay no tax.

So, the question becomes when the most successful company in the world doesn't pay taxes, who does pay taxes? And it's simple, less successful companies pay taxes. You know, Alexa, is this a good thing?

MCDOWELL: Absolutely. I want to ask you, though, about with Facebook and its future. Do you think that the problem was -- you look at -- I was talking to a well-known investor yesterday and he said the government just stood back and did nothing because they have no understanding of technology and they don't want to, quote, get in the way of innovation. That Amazon - - that Facebook should never have been allowed to buy Instagram, for example, that they just let the company get bigger and bigger and bigger with no control.

GALLOWAY: Well, going back to Herman's comments, I don't think the revolution is going to be consumer-led. I think consumers are lazy and talk of big game about supply chain ethics and then want that little black dress for 9.99 and their espresso pods delivered within 48 hours for free. I don't think this is going to be consumer-led. And when 280 million Americans, 213 million of them are on Facebook, you don't really have any choice. In addition, when you have 5 million advertisers and no one advertiser can really hurt you, you're a monopsony. Advertisers have no choice but to be on Facebook. So, bottom line, this is a monopoly. I think the answer is to break these guys up, Facebook, Instagram, messenger, WhatsApp, healthier for the economy.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: You can take your mic off. Drop it. Great for you. That was a drop-the-mic moment. Scott Galloway, thank you so much.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Merger talks between Sprint and T-Mobile, reportedly back on. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange with more. Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN ANCHOR: Hey, good morning, Dagen. So, yesterday, we saw Sprint soaring 17 percent, T-Mobile also jumping. So now, this is the third time in four years that these two companies are getting together. Last round of talks broke up at the end of November. They've now rekindled with the talks because they want to share the burden of investing and all the costs that they face. But now, it's who's going to have control. Because you have GermanDeutsche Telekom, they're seeking control. They obviously are the part of the T-Mobile. And then you have SoftBank Group that is -- has a majority stake for Sprint. So, this is what they're ironing out. But again, they're still in the early stages, so don't get too excited.

And the other story that is sort of the back story is that the cell tower stocks have been under pressure because they have concerns that they might have to cut their costs. Let's look at Spotify. Spotify's an exciting story, right? We had a direct listing, the reference price is 132. But now they're saying -- and they soared at the open and it's been doing great. Big product change, free music service that they're going to be pushing going forward. They have their 9.99, but Spotify is looking down about one percent today. And watch on April 24th, they may have a new speaker. They're going to have an announcement. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Nicole. Nicole Petallides at the New York Stock Exchange. Markets under pressure this morning over rising tensions with Syria and of course Russia. In a pair of tweets earlier, President Trump threatened the Kremlin over its defense of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and said their relations with Russia are worse than ever. Joining me now is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney. Stuart, your thoughts?

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: Well, actually, Dagen, I think the President was tweeting and saying very clearly, here come the missiles, watch out, boys, because they're on their way virtually. I think we can expect a strike. I mean, the President has teed this up quite obviously. We can expect a strike in the relatively near future. My question is how does the Market react? Granted, you're down 200 on Dow Futures at the moment as you run up to the in expected strike but what happens when the strike takes place? Does the market fall some more or does it recover?

I remember in times past when as soon as the missiles are fired off, the Market goes up. It goes down as you wait for the fire. And then it goes up when they've been fired. I wonder if the same thing will happen this time. I think a lot depends on the extent of the missile hit, whether Russian and/or Iranians get killed in the hit, and any possibility that they'll be followed up with more later? I think the market reaction depends on that. But I would not be surprised to see a move up when those missiles are launched.

MCDOWELL: This is President Trump using Twitter in the best way, to communicate very forcefully and directly.

VARNEY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And people always wring their hands and nash about how Trump is on Twitter so much. But this, you can't get more direct and powerful than the statements he made just out.

VARNEY: It's immediate, isn't it? I mean, it's flat-out immediate. He comes -- he tweets, and you know full well that the Russians are waiting for the tweet. They're not waiting for a statement from the State Department, they're looking for the tweet. And reliably, here it is. By the way, I hope I'm not offending my friend there, Scott Galloway. I know what a socialist he is. I know how he obviously dislikes the whole idea of American military adventures overseas. I don't want to upset the guy in the middle of your show, OK? I just want that to be very clear.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: OK. I love you, Stuart. You're on in nine minutes. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: This breaking news right here, right now. House Speaker Paul Ryan will announce today that he will not run for re-election and he will retire at the end of the year. He plans to tell the GOP House members today that he will not seek re-election. Herman, your take on this.

CAIN: Well, it's a loss for the Republicans to lose that seat. But they might hold the seat but secondly, it means a change in leadership for the Republicans in the House. And to be honest with you, that may not be a bad thing. Because when Ryan was running for the speaker's position, there were a number of people vying for it. So, it's going to open up the competition for people who really want to be in that. And secondly, I happen to believe that Ryan may have just said I've had enough. You can't imagine the pressure that you are under to try to basically herd 245 cats uphill and that's just the Republican side, in order to get something done.

MCDOWELL: The thing about what happened just last year, in President Trump's first year in office, the House got an Obamacare fix passed, what would have been a giant fix of Medicaid. What did the Senate do with it? Gave it a thumbs down. Paul Ryan, clearly, when Maria interviewed him in mid-February, he was very clearly upset about that no-vote from Senator John McCain. Then they got the tax reform through, which I've been a naysayer among many, I didn't think they would be able to get it done, that he would be able to accomplish that. So, he has that huge win under his belt, time to hit the bricks.

CAIN: He is leaving with a grand slam homerun under his belt and that is the tax cuts and jobs plan, you're absolutely right. So, it's going to be will be a horse race.

MCSHANE: There's a number of conservatives though -- no secret -- that aren't big fans of Paul Ryan. That said, he did -- he did raise a lot of money for all the criticism that came in from him for the base. So,now you have a dynamic right in the midterm election where the speaker has already apparently going to announce that he's not running. That's your main fundraiser, too, that's kind of out of the game, and kind of the backdrop of everything else that's going on. You'll have a run for Republican leadership. I wonder how it affects the dynamic, I guess is the -- is the main question.

CAIN: It will be interesting. I think we'll have to wait and see. Because that is a major, major change with respect to the dynamics of politics for 2018.

MCDOWELL: And I do want to point out that there was a report out that -- of the Republicans who were expected to have dinner with President Trump tonight, House Speaker Paul Ryan being one of them, Kevin McCarthy, John Cornyn, and Mitch McConnell will be -- we'll see if the dinner plan is changed, but again, it -- I wonder if this actually helps bring enthusiasm at the base. Paul Ryan's not the most well-liked people --

CAIN: I would agree, 50 percent of the base was not that enthusiastic about his leadership. So, it could possibly bring some enthusiasm to the base.

MCDOWELL: I didn't -- think it's safe to say he wasn't as hated as John Boehner.

CAIN: Oh, no, no, no, no. Not in the least. But he got a big job done, the tax cuts and jobs plan.

MCSHANE: Do you think there's no marijuana company he wants to be on the board of? No, I don't think so.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: It's all over my head.

MCSHANE: Sorry.

MCDOWELL: Does Paul Ryan want to run for a higher office? We'll be right back, everybody.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Thanks all, Herman Cain. Stuart Varney, take it away.

VARNEY: I shall. Good morning, Dagen, and good morning, everyone. The President orders the Harry S. Truman carrier battle group to the Mideast.

END

urn:contentItem:5TSW-NYK1-JBSS-S1CX-00000-00More than $1 trillion in Big Tech value wiped out2018-11-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisMore than $1 trillion in Big Tech value wiped outBy Paul R. La Monica, CNN BusinessNEW YORK (CNN Business)

NEW YORK (CNN Business) -- The recent stock market meltdown has hit the tech sector particularly hard. How hard? A sextet of well-known techs -- Apple, Amazon, Microsoft, Google owner Alphabet, Facebook and Netflix -- have lost a collective $1.1 trillion from their all-time highs.

These companies, which some have dubbed the Fab 6, bounced back a bit with the overall market Wednesday. But they are in a correction, down more than 10% from recent peaks.

In fact, several of them are even in bear market territory -- 20% or more below their highs.

Investors are clearly reevaluating whether the tech sector, which has led the market's surge for the past few years, deserves to remain a leader on Wall Street.

There are growing concerns that demand for high-priced gadgets like Apple's (AAPL) iPhones are beginning to slow.

Several iPhone suppliers have recently warned of weak sales and Bloomberg reported Wednesday that China's Foxconn Technology Group, which makes iPhones for Apple, is planning significant cost cuts next year. coo

Foxconn Technology Group would neither confirm nor deny the Bloomberg story, saying in a statement to CNN Business that it regularly reviews its global operations and that "the review being carried out by our team this year is no different than similar exercises carried out in past years."

There's a growing possibility of more government regulations on tech -- particularly advertising based companies such as Facebook (FB) and Google (GOOGL).

Amazon's (AMZN) increased clout in retail, cloud computing and media has some wondering if the company could eventually find itself the target of antitrust investigations around the globe, similar to Microsoft (MSFT) back in the late 1990s.

Finally, there's the simple matter of whether or not the big tech companies deserve their lofty valuations. Amazon and Netflix (NFLX) each trade for about 60 times 2019 earnings forecasts -- a huge premium to the broader market.

Big slide leads to buying opportunities

So what's next for the tech sector?

Dave Smith, senior vice president of domestic equities with Bailard, said the recent slide has led to the proverbial case of babies being thrown out with the bathwater -- panic selling that has led to "particularly stark punishment" for some top tech stocks.

"There are a lot of attractive growth stocks that are now trading at steep discounts," Smith said. "These are the ones that we want to own."

Smith, who is also the subadviser for the Nationwide Bailard Technology and Science Fund, said that semiconductor stocks in particular are looking like good values.

According to Morningstar, that fund had chip leaders Texas Instruments (TXN), Nvidia (NVDA) and Broadcom (AVGO) among its top 25 holdings at the end of October. The fund's top five holdings were Microsoft, Facebook, Apple, Alphabet and Cisco (CSCO).

Adam Phillips, director of portfolio strategy at EP Wealth Advisors, also said it might be time to go shopping in the tech sector.

Phillips said it's still "too early to sound the all clear" on volatility but he noted that he recently bought some Amazon shares because he thinks there was "indiscriminate selling" in the stock in the past few weeks.

There's another reason why tech may rebound too. More mergers could be on the horizon, especially if earnings growth and the economy start to slow.

Daniel Ives, an analyst with Wedbush Securities, said in a recent report that the sell-off in software stocks in particular may lead to more deals, especially in the lucrative cloud computing market. To that end, IBM (IBM) just plunked down $34 billion for Red Hat.

And Ives noted that Alphabet, which just hired away Oracle's (ORCL) cloud guru Thomas Kurian to lead Google Cloud, could now be "on the war path" for cloud deals in order to compete more effectively with Microsoft and Amazon.

So 2019 could be the year that big tech companies start to put even more of their gigantic cash hoards to use for acquisitions.

CNN's Jordan Valinsky contributed to this report.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S04-YDJ1-DXY4-X264-00000-00More Than Just a Sell-Off in Tech?: DealBook Briefing2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:38ZLexisNexisSection Column 0Business/Financial DeskPg. More Than Just a Sell-Off in Tech?: DealBook Briefing

Good Wednesday. Here's what we're watching.

Are we witnessing the end of the tech mania?

Amazon has shed more than $50 billion in market value.

Are investors waking up to Tesla's real problem?

Mark Zuckerberg agreed to testify before Congress.

SoftBank and Saudi Arabia are planning the world's largest solar energy project.

Get this in your inbox each morning. Sign up here.

Are we witnessing the end of a mania?

Investors, always willing to believe in technology companies, spent the last three years piling into the shares of companies like Facebook, Amazon and Netflix with special abandon. Now the intellectual underpinnings of the tech rally are being seriously tested.

Stocks in the best-known tech companies have plunged in recent days. The NYSE FANG+ index, which tracks the share price of 10 companies, including Facebook, Apple and Amazon, has fallen nearly 14 percent from its recent high. Given that the index has soared 50 percent in just the past 12 months, the recent decline could just be the sort of sell-off that punctuates any long-term rally.

Still, several large tech companies suddenly face challenges that could undermine their ability to transform whole industries. And as we've seen after previous fervors, investors can take a long time to regain their faith.

Facebook is down 20 percent from its recent high. Most of the slide came after news reports showing how the company's data was misused. Investors have to grapple with the possibility that Facebook won't be sharing as much data as it does, undermining its ability to generate ever-increasing amounts of advertising revenue.

Nvidia, a computer chip maker intent on being a leader in automated driving technology, is off 12 percent from its recent high. The company said on Tuesday that it would halt tests of its autonomous driving technology on public roads after an Uber self-driving car hit and killed a pedestrian in Arizona.

Tesla is not a tech stock, but it is included in the FANG+ index, and its supporters believe deeply in its power to revolutionize the auto industry. Growing fears about Tesla's ability to finance its expansion have helped drag its stock down 33 percent from its recent high. Ominously, the price of Tesla's bonds is also falling, signaling that the company is losing the confidence of creditors.

Of course, on their march higher, tech stocks overcame obstacles, like management problems at Uber and the poor performance of Snap's initial public offering.

But the latest problems have raised deeper, broader doubts, and that may keep the uncertainty around longer. Investors have viewed automated driving technology as a huge potential source of growth for some companies. But after the Uber incident in Arizona, those companies may take a more realistic look at what they have to spend to create a technology that is efficient and safe, and conclude that they have to pull out of the race or pare back. Users of social media and regulators may prevent social media companies from sharing so much of their data with advertisers, and that could restrain revenue growth.

And if the passion for two or three big tech companies wanes, the cooling may spread.

-- Peter Eavis

Amazon has shed more than $50 billion in market value.

The reason?

Reports that President Trump wants to rein in the e-commerce giant.

Jonathan Swan of Axios, citing anonymous sources, reported:

''Trump has talked about changing Amazon's tax treatment because he's worried about mom-and-pop retailers being put out of business.''

Mr. Swan added:

''Trump's wealthy friends tell him Amazon is destroying their businesses. His real estate buddies tell him -- and he agrees -- that Amazon is killing shopping malls and brick-and-mortar retailers.''

Shares of Amazon have tumbled more than 7 percent at one point Wednesday, but they pared those losses after a White House official told Reuters there were no specific policy changes related to Amazon being considered at the moment. But the official added that the administration is always looking at different options on a range of policy issues.

How concerned should investors be?

GBH Insights analyst Daniel Ives writes:

''While it's now a hand holding time for Amazon given this new regulatory potential threat, we believe the reality of these worries altering the company's business model and future tax structure are low and we would be buyers of the name on weakness.''

Guess which companies are benefiting from Amazon's woes? Retailers, the FT points out.

On a day when the stocks on Wall Street are flat, Macy's was up 3.5 percent, J.C. Penney has gained 5.5 percent, Walmart rose 1.7 percent, Target increased 1.8 percent, and Kohl's was up 2.4 percent.

Are investors waking up to Tesla's real problem?

The electric carmaker's shares are down 7 percent Wednesday, after plunging 8 percent on Tuesday.

Tuesday's slide was driven, in part, by the National Transportation Safety Board's announcement that it was investigating a fatal crash last week involving a Tesla vehicle in California. News that JaguarLand Rover was teaming up with Alphabet Inc.'s Waymo unit probably didn't help either.

But the continued decline in Tesla's stock -- its shares are down more than 20 percent since mid-March -- speaks to the bigger concern surrounding Tesla: How it funds itself.

Investors have grown increasingly worried as Tesla burns through cash and struggles to meet its own production goals for the Model 3. Late Tuesday, Moody's downgraded Tesla's credit rating further into junk territory and said its outlook on the company is negative. The credit ratings agency cited production delays and said Tesla may soon need to raise more than $2 billion.

Those concerns can be seen not just in Tesla's stock price but also in the trading of its debt. The FT points out that ''Tesla's eight-year bond maturing in 2025 traded on Wednesday at 87.6 cents to the dollar, the lowest since issuance. The yield has surged to 7.5 percent from 6.59 percent on Monday.''

Liam Denning of Bloomberg Gadfly writes:

''Challenges on the factory floor and the balance sheet are converging. Drawing inexorably closer to a refinancing wall, Tesla needs a real shot of confidence, and capital, to keep its money machine turning over this year.

''Given Tuesday's bond blowout, that almost certainly means tapping the equity market again. Nothing like being a motivated seller to put a floor under a stock price, right?''

Is Twitter vulnerable to privacy regulation?

The fallout from Facebook's Cambridge Analytica scandal has spread to Twitter.

The stock tumbled 12 percent Tuesday after Citron Research's Andrew Left said he was betting against the social media company because of its vulnerability to regulation around how it handles user data.

But analysts at Barclays disagree. They argue in a recent note to clients that Twitter's data business likely won't be impacted much by any regulation on its use of user data.

Meet Equifax's new C.E.O.

The credit reporting company named Mark Begor, a private equity executive who once led General Electric's credit card business, as its new chief executive.

Mr. Begor, 59, takes over for Paulino do Rego Barros Jr., who has filled the role on an interim basis since September, when Richard F. Smith stepped down after a data breach exposed sensitive personal information, including Social Security numbers, of 148 million people.

Mr. Begor will start at Equifax on April 16.

About Mr. Begor

The 59-year-old is a managing director at the private equity firm Warburg Pincus. He is also a member of the board at the credit-scoring company FICO.

Mr. Begor spent 35 years at General Electric, where his duties included leading the conglomerate's real-estate investment and energy management units. For nine years, he was president and chief executive of the company's consumer credit business, which was later spun off as Synchrony Financial.

His pay package

Equifax said it would give Mr. Begor stock and options valued at $17 million this year and an annual salary and bonus of up to $4.5 million.

Why the first Trump trade deal may not lead to others

President Trump has scored a significant trade deal with South Korea.

But with Mr. Trump preparing to meet with North Korea's leader, Kim Jong-un -- who just took an armored train trip to Beijing -- and the North apparently pressing on with nuclear developments, an ''America first'' trade stance was far from the only thing pushing the South to sign. More from Michael D. Shear and Alan Rappeport:

The political success of the trade agreement -- and its ability to be replicated in other negotiations -- is not guaranteed. Many countries have reacted coolly to Washington's pugilistic approach to trade, viewing the president's preference to punch first and negotiate later as counter to global interests.

The Trump administration continues to ramp up its trade rhetoric with China. Unidentified sources told Bloomberg that it is considering invoking an emergency law to restrict Chinese investments in sensitive U.S. tech. A separate plan to enact tariffs on $60 billion of Chinese goods has left companies wondering which industries will be targeted. Other Asian countries increasingly fear being caught in the crossfire of a trade war, the WSJ reports.

And nations are already reacting to Trump's trade moves, erecting barriers to stop the steel and aluminum that faces tariffs in the U.S. being dumped in their markets.

Against this background, NXP sold its 40 percent stake in a Chinese joint venture on chip design.

A reality check for tech?

Companies like Facebook, Amazon and Alphabet have delivered some of the best returns to investors in recent years, powered by the achievements and the promise of social media and artificial intelligence.

But that confidence is evaporating, as investors brace for intensified regulatory scrutiny across the industry. Tech stocks took a pummeling yesterday and in early European trading.

Twitter dropped 12 percent after Andrew Left's Citron Research said it was shorting the company.

Critic's corner: The ''sector's growing clout over everyday life also raises the risks of what can go wrong,'' Dan Gallagher argues at WSJ's Heard on the Street.

Mark Zuckerberg will face the music

The public outcry over Facebook's data and privacy settings has grown loud enough that Mark Zuckerberg now says he's willing to testify to Congress. The company is on a hiring spree for lobbyists, too, and unnamed sources say it's putting off the promotion of new home products.

The man who started all this, the Cambridge Analytica whistle-blower Christopher Wylie, spoke to British lawmakers on Tuesday and revealed that an employee of Palantir Technologies had suggested that Cambridge Analytica build an app to gain access to Facebook networks. Palantir was co-founded by Peter Thiel, who sits on the Facebook board.

Separately, New Zealand's privacy commissioner has accused Facebook of breaking a law by refusing to give a man information about him held in other users' accounts. Fair housing groups are suing over ad targeting, saying Facebook still lets advertisers discriminate. And three Facebook Messenger users are suing on privacy grounds.

The self-driving slowdown continues

Nvidia -- the chip maker whose autonomous-vehicle technology is used by Volkswagen, Tesla, Audi and hundreds of other firms -- said it would halt its own tests on self-driving cars, after an autonomous Uber vehicle struck and killed a pedestrian in Arizona. Its shares dropped 7.8 percent.

Here's Roger Lanctot, an automotive technology analyst with Strategy Analytics:

Nvidia has no choice but to take steps in the context of the fear, uncertainty and outrage likely to be stimulated by a robot car killing a human being. This is precisely the type of event that is capable of slaying a nascent industry in the crib.

Tesla also tumbled 8.2 percent, after the National Transportation Safety Board said it was conducting its second crash investigation of the year involving one of the company's cars. There's also anxiety about whether it will hit production goals.

Uber said it would not renew its California permit for self-driving vehicle tests until investigations were complete in Arizona. And it's facing questions over a decision to scale back on safety sensors.

But Waymo said it still intended to put thousands of self-driving cars -- customized Jaguar I-Paces, to be precise -- on the road over the next two years.

Critic's corner: Timothy B. Lee argues in Ars Technica that Uber should sell its self-driving project, which needed a firm with a ''methodical, safety-oriented culture.''

The tech flyaround

Uber has settled a discrimination lawsuit from three female software engineers for $10 million. (Recode)

Ransomware has hobbled the city government in Atlanta. (NYT)

Apple unveiled a new iPad aimed at classrooms, where Google has raced ahead. (NYT)

Oracle won a federal appeal in its multibillion-dollar copyright infringement claim against Google, in a way that could make software developers easier to sue. (WSJ)

Google bought the GIF platform Tenor. (Verge)

Snapchat is building a way for people to use their account with third-party apps, Facebook-style. (Recode)

Robert Mercer, of Renaissance and Cambridge Analytica fame, is also a volunteer police officer in Lake Arthur, N.M. (Bloomberg)

The Washington flyaround

The former Supreme Court justice John Paul Stevens has called for the Second Amendment to be repealed, in an NYT Op-Ed. Bloomberg looked at how the bankruptcy of the gun maker Remington Outdoor would affect the people suing it for as much as $500 million. And the N.R.A. said it accepted funds from foreign sources, but did not spend them on election campaigns.

At least 12 states say they would sue if the Trump administration seeks to add a question about citizenship to the 2020 census. A less accurate census -- if, say, fewer immigrants were to respond -- could distort both government spending and the House of Representatives.

The F.B.I. found continuing ties between Russian intelligence and a business associate of the former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort, according to court documents filed by the special counsel's team. (WaPo)

A Republican plan for the midterm elections: more tax cuts. (Politico)

SoftBank and Saudi Arabia team up to build a solar park

The $200 billion solar power project would be the largest in the world and could help Saudi Arabia lessen its dependence on oil.

But Jenny Chase, head of solar analysis at BNEF, told Bloomberg: ''It is worth noting that many of these memorandums of understanding do not result in anything happening.''

Saudi officials were in New York as part of a tour by Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, who spoke to the NYT, urging a tough line on Iran. And Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund said it was considering opening offices around the world.

Deals flyaround

Takeda Pharmaceutical said it was considering a bid for Shire that could improve its position in drugs for cancer, gastrointestinal disease and nervous system ailments. (Bloomberg)

Potential bidders for GlaxoSmithKline's health nutrition business could include Nestlé, Kraft Heinz and Unilever, unnamed sources say. (Reuters)

The real estate broker Cushman & Wakefield is interviewing I.P.O. advisers, unnamed sources say. (Bloomberg)

Tyson Foods has hired Goldman Sachs to explore the sale of its pizza crust business. (FT)

In a cross-examination during their big merger case, the lead lawyer for AT&T and Time Warner pushed back against the description of Time Warner's content as ''must-have.'' (CNN)

The Carolina Panthers football team could fetch a record sale price of about $2.5 billion. (NYT)

Publishers' #MeToo dilemma

Books are on hold and deals are being canceled as the publishing sector grapples with accusations of sexual harassment by authors and others.

But the response has not been universal, as publishers weigh lost profits against reputational risks in an industry dominated by women.

Separately, former employees at Wynn Resorts said that managers had for years ignored or dismissed complaints about Steve Wynn's conduct toward women. A former Miramax employee appeared before British lawmakers today to seek a change in the law on nondisclosure agreements.

The speed read

The chief executive of Deutsche Bank, whoever it is, will face a challenge regaining investors' trust: its share price is less than 40 percent of the net worth stated on its balance sheet and it relies a lot on potentially unpredictable Wall Street revenue.

Wu Xiaihui, former chairman of the Chinese insurer Anbang, went on trial in Shanghai. (FT)

A key player at the birth of Berkshire Hathaway's health venture with Amazon and JPMorgan: the Berkshire investment manager Todd Combs. (Bloomberg)

The former Lloyds Banking Group chief Eric Daniels has won a legal battle over a bonus worth $2.1 million. It was withheld from him after the bank needed a government bailout. (Times of London)

Netflix's talent hunting is pushing up Hollywood salaries. (Bloomberg)

How much would a Warren Buffett investment help G.E.? (Bloomberg Gadfly)

Know someone who would enjoy this newsletter? Tell them to sign up here.

You can find live updates throughout the day at nytimes.com/dealbook.

We'd love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com
